text:
Very creamy and yummy. If you think your sauce is too runny before pouring it over the macaroni, it's not. I was very nervous that my sauce was not thick enough, but once I poured it over the macaroni and baked it, the dish turned out wonderful!

text:
I have to laugh at the one who rated this 1 star for the fat and calories... who makes low cal mac & cheese? :)  This is a great recipe.  Prepare yourself for a heartattack on a plate but well worth it.  I added onion powder, garlic powder, paprika and used crumbled ritz crackers as the topping.  I thought the sauce was too runny when I poured it in the pan, but as the others said, it really thickens up when in the oven. My 2 year old loves it as do we.  We accompanied it with steamed broccoli for a little healthy upswing.

text:
Rave reviews at my house. Can only give 4 stars though as I followed someone else's tips on reducing milk to 1/2C. Adding 2C evapo. milk and 1/2C sour cream. I decided to double the recipe so that we would have leftovers the next day. I put half the mix in one casserole dish and the other in another dish. Baked one and stored the other un-baked one in the fridge to be put in the oven 1/2 hour before dinner the next day. Do not worry that the sauce seems runny when you add it to the noodles. It thickens up A LOT! Right after the cheese melts add it to the noodles and you're in business.

text:
Rich & Creamy. Looked a little bland, so I added minced garlic (1 tbsp), dry mustard powder (1/2 tsp)& used fresh shredded romano instead of parmesan (if you do use parmesan, use fresh shredded, if you use the grated Kraft kind in the shaker, sauce wont be smooth). Show patience with the roux. If yours came out lumpy, you didnt cook roux right or long enough (stir constantly when cooking roux)

text:
I had to try this recipe ever since I read the rating critizing it for being loaded with "fat" ie CHEESE... Duh, that's what Mac and cheese is about!! I made it with large elbow macaroni so the sauce got all inside the pasta... thru in an extra 1/2 inch slice of Velveeta and some white pepper, and jazzed up the crumbs by mixing the crumbs, melted butter, paprika, onion powder, salt & pepper and then sprinkling over the top.  Very good "old-home" taste!!

text:
I agree that a dash of dry mustard is missing from this recipe.   Also, if you realllly want a rich taste, try substituting half of the milk with evaporated milk.  The evaporated milk gives Mac & Cheese an amazingly rich & creamy taste.  Other than those two things, it's pretty good!

text:
This recipe is delicious!  If you are wondering what 8 oz. of elbow macaroni should be in cups, it is 1 3/4 cups.  Also, bake it in an 8 x 8 glass pan.  It fits perfectly. I mixed the bread crumbs with melted butter and spread it on top of the mac and cheese and it browned in the oven.  This is now one of our family favorites.

text:
This turned out a little wierd for me.  I make my mom's mac and cheese recipe all the time, and that one is very creamy, even after being baked.  This one was creamy until I baked it.  It seemed to firm up in the oven a lot, almost dry out a little.  I didn't like it at first, but ended up liking it more as I ate it, and had a second helping.  ;)  I really liked the bread crumbs on top.  (I used Panko bread crumbs).  Like other reviewers said, it is a little bland, and I even added hot sauce, worchestire sauce, chili powder, garlic powder, garlic powder and spicy brown mustard.  It does call for a lot of milk; maybe it needs a little more cheese?  All in all, it was easy to make and satisfying, just not spectacular.  Would have given it three stars, but my babies loved it!

text:
"This Mac and Chese is EVIL!!!" At least that was all I could hear my girlfriend mumbling between big bites. I took the advise of other reviewers and used a can of evaporated milk in place of some of the milk. The cheese melts nicely and thickens wonderfully. I also used rotini pasta instead of elbow noodles because it holds the cheese sauce better. For you new cooks...you have to heat the flour to a high enough temperature for the thickening process to work...just don't boil it. Don't make this too often, its deadly!

None
country:
None
text:
The keys to this recipe are to make the roux very slowly so that it does not get lumpy, and don't worry about how liquid the sauce seems - it firms up nicely in the oven.  I used only 1 cup milk, and used 1 cup evaporated milk, 1/2 cup sour cream, and 1/2 cup half & half, which I think helped with the runniness.  I added 1/2 cup of gorgonzola to this recipe to give it an extra kick, and think I might add even more next time.  I also added a little worceister and mustard powder to the sauce, and think I might add more next time.  This was a very easy recipe to make!

text:
This is a great basic recipe for mac and cheese.  I followed other suggestions by using 1/2 cup of milk, 1 3/4 cup of evaporated milk (didn't have enough for a full 2 cups), 1/2 cup of sour cream.  I also followed the advice of others taking my time when making the cheese sauce.  My cheese sauce came out perfect.  I used sharp cheddar, asiago, and colby jack.  I used about 2 cups of each kind of cheese.  My sauce came out thick because of the amount of cheese I used but I don't mind because I love cheese.  I also added salt, pepper, garlic powder, and mustard for seasoning.  I made this for a pot luck at work and got lots of compliments.  This recipe is a keeper!

I don't get this recipe at all? It has a "full bag of cheese," but it is so "BLAND!" It tasted like homemade milk, noodles, and breadcrumbs. I tried to salvage it by scraping off some of the hefty bread crumbs, which ended up being way too much, and adding a different more flavorful cheese and re-baking. But, it was no luck. It stayed equally as bland but, it only became more grainy. I guess the creamy goodness from mac n cheese comes from good sauce basics. I really wanted to like this, as the picture with the topping looked so good! I was not sure how to modify it though? I hate to rate recipes this low, but unfortunately it was a big waste of ingredients, with all of the cheese, as it ended up getting tossed out.

text:
If you find it bland, here are some suggestions from other readers.   Make sure you liberally salt your macaroni water.  Use evaporated milk and 1/2 C sour cream. added plenty of black pepper, about 1/2 tsp. of dry mustard, 1/2 onion, chopped and sauteed, a dash of worstershire sauce 
Some also added 1/2 block of cream cheese, 1 cup of mozzarella with very sharp cheese.
Cook crispy bacon mixed with crushed croutons instead of bread crumbs or Ritz crackers.

text:
this is by far the best mac and cheese recipe i have ever encountered!  the roux made the sauce so thick and cheesy without the "floury" taste.  I didn't have elbow macaroni so i used the spirals (i find they catch the sauce better.  i also added chicken, which i cut up, seasoned with salt and pepper, pan-fried it in olive oil until browned.  i mixed the chicken in with the noodles before pouring the sauce.  oh, also, try toasting the breadcrumbs (just as the recipe says) in the same pan you cook the chicken in!  the leftover browned chicken bits adds soooo much flavor.  Major hit with my roommate and my boyfriend!!!

city:

None
text:
There huge error in this recipe... Or perhaps typo? It should not be 8oz of pasta, but 16 oz. This yields 8 servings. That would take care of most of the "soupy" complaints. As for the bland complaints it's a simple fix. The recipe calls for "sharp cheddar cheese" much more flavor than mild. Another good hint is to always salt you pasta water (should taste like sea water). 
With that said, this recipe was awesome. The simplicity of it makes it flexible. To excite the palate a bit more I've started adding onion power, paprika, and cumin to the cheese sauce. I also added baccon alot of parsley; mainly for color. The breadcrumbs are my favorite part of this dish. I did find that they were a bit soggy. I've altered this part only by adding them the last 10 minutes of cooking. Thank you so much for this recipe. My cheese loving family appreciates it.

text:
I loved this recipe but doctored it to my tasting.  Instead of 3 cups of milk, I used two cups, plus 1/2 cup of sour cream and 1/2 cup of half-n-half.  Instead of the 1/2 grated parmesan cheese, I used 1 cup of Monterey Jack, plus I sprinkled grated parmesan into the mix.  I used two dashes of mustard powder to give it an extra kick, and also added a cup of ham to make the meal complete!  Instead of bread-crumbs, I substituted croutons, maybe 1/4 cup.  Delicious--I'll definitely make it again!

I made this as a side with Christmas dinner so the kids would have something to eat and I think the adults enjoyed it even more!  I give it 4 stars as rated because of the changes I made according to reviews.  I doubled the macaroni and cheddar cheese, yet kept the same amount of milk, buter and flour and it came out perfect. This ones going in my recipe book!

text:
The best macaroni and cheese  ever made or tasted! It’s not too runny or soupy at all and makes great leftovers (not that it lasts that long in my house). I used Vermont sarp ceddar and Parmesan. I really liked the taste the white chesses created. I can’t stand the kind of macaroni from a box that reminds me of cafeteria food. This recipe is unmistakably baked and homemade. Anyone who says they don’t like macaroni and cheese has never tried this recipe. When I lost the recipe I knew I could enjoy any other kind so I went searching for it on this site. This one is definitely going in my personal recipe book.

text:
I think this recipe is pretty good. There were some people on here that thought it was too bland. My suggestion is to use sharp cheddar. The sharper the better. I used a mixture of New York White Sharp Cheddar and just regular Sharp Cheddar. Make sure you salt the sauce before putting it into your pan. It was delicious. The bread crumbs added a lot of flavor. My husband and I gobbled it up! For those of you who thought it was too lumpy: you have to whisk the flour and butter together. Continue to whisk while you SLOWLY add the milk. It came out perfect for me. I will make this in the future!

text:
loved this recipe, doubled it with no problems. however, it may have turned out better due to the following changes I made: only 1/2 cup of milk, with 2 cups of evaporated milk and 1/2 cup sour cream for a creamier texture. added a clove of garlic, 1 diced sauteed onion and some spices to the sauce as the recipe seemed sort of bland with just the milk, roux and cheeses. and for the topping I used crushed croutons browned in butter. this is a very quick and simple recipe that I will turn to again! but I definitely recommend adding something a little extra to your sauce if you want something a little more tasty. and the croutons turned out a lot crunchier on top than the baked breadcrumbs.

country:
None
text:
Tasty, and your picky kids will eat it too.  This is an incredibly fattening and high-calorie dish, so I think the serving size should be smaller.  This recipe serves about 6 in my family. I cut down the milk to 2.5 cups, and it was plenty creamy.  Added a bit of garlic powder and some pepper, too, for some needed flavor.  My recommendation: bake this first for 25 minutes without the bread crumb topping.  Take it out of the oven and mix it up, allowing the extra liquid to evaporate. Then, sprinkle on the bread crumb topping and bake for another 5-7 minutes.

Turned out good and creamy with patience cooking the sauce, continued stirring and cooking a little longer than you think to make sure the flour really is done so it won't turn out grainy.  I doubled the recipe, and used 5 cups of extra sharp cheddar instead of 4.  Also, I didn't have parmesan so used a cup of a shredded cheese mix of mozzerella, romano, asiago, and parmesan. I spiced it up with some worcestershire sauce, garlic powder, and dry mustard.  Everyone raved about it!

text:
I offered to my little boy that I'd make him ANY treat he wanted if he hurried through his chores Saturday morning, I was expecting cookies, cupcakes or bars, but he asked for "real mac n cheese, not from a box!"  "Umm, OK."  So I popped onto my handy allrecipes app, and once again you pulled through for me!  

I was really worried because every time I'd ever had homemade mac it was at a buffet with way over cooked noodles, or when a family member made it, it was just dried up noodles with melted and dried cheese, with milk literally poured over the top of it.  Needless to say I was pretty nervous.

I didn't have Parmesan, or cheddar, just some Colby and Jack, and I didn't have bread or bread crumbs, but I went ahead with the modified recipe, buddy was charging through his chores!  I doubled the recipe and baked it in a glass 9x13 casserole.  I made sure to cook the noodles al dente, when I popped it into the oven my son finished his chores and pouted looking at the empty pot, he'd though he'd missed out, but he was thrilled to see it baking away in the oven.  We had a big sit down lunch, all 5 of us, and everyone filled their bellies while ohhing and awwing about the yummy pasta.  There was plenty left for dinner, so I mixed it with the left over California mix steamed veggies, and there was dinner!  Success!  Thanks Allrecipes!

Three stars because it is incredibly easy to make [I followed the recipe to the letter], but I couldn't give it more stars for two reasons. First, it is bland. Bland, bland, bland and bland. It definitely needs some added zing - even salt and pepper would have help. Next time I will definitely add spices.  Also, I really didn't like the texture of the parmesan cheese after I served it.  All the cheese melted wonderfully and the sauce was great but once served it was a bit grainy. I didn't like it. Next time I will use all cheddar. 
 
I, too, found the person who gave it one star for the fat and calories to be hysterical.  What do  you expect? It's pasta and cheese. heehee
 
Definitely try this recipe but doctor it up to give it some taste.

text:
This is a great recipe! My boyfriend lamented for days when the leftovers were finished. The only changes I made were to add fresh broccoli in the middle and more seasoning to the cheese sauce. I blanched the broccoli and set aside while I prepared the rest of the meal, I poured half the macaroni in the baking dish, sprinkled a layer of shredded cheddar, then broccoli, another sprinkle of cheddar, the rest of the macaroni, then poured the cheese sauce slowly over the the whole thing. The sauce is thin but it baked up to mix through out. To the cheese sauce I added some cayenne and chili powder, a little salt and pepper and some mustard powder.

This is a really yummy recipe, and whether you use Velveeta or cheddar is simply a personal preference.  I use extra-sharp cheddar, omit the breadcrumbs, and put onion powder in the sauce. Also use more cheddar, shredded, on the top, and sprinkle paprika over all. I make a thinner roux because it does thicken up while baking.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a recipe that doesn't require a fake cheese sauce and I stumbled across this one.  I think it is a good basic recipe that will allow you to experiment.  I made a few changes. For starters I only used 2 cups of milk, I like my mac and cheese not so creamy, and I used a blend of Sharp Cheddar cheese and Montery Jack. I added some garlic powder, onion powder, salt & pepper and parsley.  Instead of elbow macaroni I used whole wheat rotini for some extra bite. I also layered some turkey pepporoni in the center which made it even more delicious and added some more flavor.  I really like the idea of adding the toasted bread crumbs on top, I usually would put parmesan cheese on top and place it in the broiler for a crunch topping, but this is much better.  Melting the cheeses before mixing it with the pasta is the key to success for this dish. I definitely will be making this again. Yummy!!!!

text:
Tasted amazing, just like homemade baked mac and cheese should. I made a double recipe and it was just enough to fill a 9x13 pan about 2-3 inches deep. Despite what the other reviews say, no substitutions are necessary. I didn't have 4 cups of shredded sharp Cheddar so I ended up using a one-pound block of American, which worked fine. Other than that, I didn't make any substitutions. I was skeptical of the need to brown the breadcrumbs in butter, but I did so anyways and it was well worth the effort. FYI, the paprika is probably optional.

text:
The cheeses in this dish make it very rich, so I added some broccoli and left-over chicken pieces to it as well and it was nice and refreshing.  I also used gluten-free pasta.  If you are using gluten free pasta, only cook the pasta a minimum amount, because it gets more cooking in the oven and you don't want to overcook gluten-free pasta.  I also added some garlic salt as well.

text:
Best home made mac and cheese I've had!  Made a couple of adjustments - I added some ground mustard, Worschtershire sauce and additional paprika for kick, as well as a package of Hormel bacon bits.  Next time I make it, I will cut the butter/bread crumb mixture in half...it was too much on the top.  Also, I would not cook the pasta completely up front - the noodles absorb a lot of the sauce and get just a little mushier than I like.

text:
Very good! I actually altered the recipe a little: I use Mexican Four Cheese instead of the Cheddar and Parmesan. I also add about 3 cloves of finely chopped garlic to the mix and only use about 1-1.5 cups of milk instead of 3 because I don't like it too creamy. For the top i just sprinkle the cheese and bread crumbs instead of melting more butter etc. Very delicious! Oh and don't forget the salt!

This was very delicious.  As other reviewers mentioned, I added some minced garlic to the cheese sauce and a little bit of salt and pepper so it would not be so bland.  Also, don’t worry about the sauce being thin; it definitely thickens after you take it out of the oven.  After I added the pasta and cheese sauce in baking pan I sprinkled grated cheddar cheese on top and pieces of bacon, then toped with panko bread crumbs....it was really tasty, when it came out of the oven!

text:
This will be the only recipe I ever use for mac and cheese.  I used good Irish Cheddar and Parm Reggiano grated myself.  Large elbows cooked al dente is the way to go in this dish.  I did add chopped jalapenos and bit of shaved or minced onion and a bit of dry mustard as well. Review:

helpfulCount:

userID:
937230
Display Name:
Debbie Elledge
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
65
favoritesCount:
449
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1243686.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this recipe. I have been looking for a mac and cheese recipe that had that creamy texture we love, not a thicker solid dish. After reading other reviews I decided to play with the recipe as far as the sauce. I wanted a 9x13 dish but didn't want to double the recipe with all that milk and cheese. I felt it safe to try a package of 12 oz egg noodles rather than 8 oz pasta b/c my past recipes used 2 cups of milk instead of 3, hoping to find a balance. This worked out great! My dish was more than 1/2 full, the sauce was a bit thinner than past ones, but as reviewers stated, it does thicken in the oven, but you are left with a nice loose creamy mixture. I agree that evaporated milk gives a nicer flavor than regular milk as it tends to be bland with that, but I didn't have any today. So I added 1 tbsp dijon mustard. For personal cheese preference I used half sharp cheddar and half colby jack. I omitted the bread crumb topping b/c my son doesn't like those on anything. Did salt and pepper to taste, but didn't alter or add anything else. This was a great flavor and texture, not bland at all. This recipe with my changes is my new mac and cheese recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this recipe is one of those types that varies based off of personal taste and texture. I was a bit deterred at first before making this because there are so many mixed reviews.. but I still gave it a shot, OF COURSE I had to change a few things to really make it my own and to how I personally felt it would taste good. the only thing I did different, was changing the breadcrumbs to my own special blend that I use for  my own homemade shake-n-bake. Mine include Garlic, Oregano, Black pepper, salt, and creole seasoning for a bit of an extra kick... other then that I pretty much followed the recipe.. the taste and texture was great to both my boyfriend and myself. The texture resembles almost all homemade mac n cheese I have ever tasted, so if you are getting a texture that is way too gritty, i'd suggest cutting down the Parmesan cheese some, to me, the more the better. 

I'd just suggest that you take the time to think of your own favorite blends to put in for taste, everyone is different and everybody's taste buds and preferences are going to be different.. make it your own and I can guarantee you that this recipe is pretty good.

text:
great base for a mac and cheese.  Like others I added a few things to fit my families "tastes" .... dry mustard, onion powder, and worcestershire sauce.  I also made it more "decadent" by using 1/2 cup of sour cream, a large can of evaporated milk, then topped off with whole milk to get the 3 cups liquid needed.  I topped it with additional cheese before adding the bread crumbs/butter to create a nice "crust" .... THANK YOU so very much for this recipe!!!!!

text:
This was very lacking in flavor, but in retrospect I should have used salted butter instead of unsalted butter. I bake a lot, so I always have unsalted butter on hand and sometimes forget that most recipes really call for salted butter. The portion is also HUGE. It says serves 4, but if you're using this as a side dish, honestly I think it serves closer to 8. Next time I'm going to halve the recipe and add more spices.

text:
I love mac and cheese, but my love for the cheesy goodness was no match for this recipe.  The bread crumbs were overpowering, the mac and cheese itself was very, very bland, and it wasn't so much creamy as it was gelatinous (possibly my fault, but I followed the recipe exactly).  Copious amounts of additional salt and pepper yielded no improvement.  I thought I'd at least save it for leftovers (I hate to waste food), but it was even worse the next day.  I'll buy a $1 box of no-brand powdered cheese mac and cheese before trying this recipe again.

text:
This was pretty good. I think I made to much of the roux, and everything got a bit thick after that. But I know what went wrong and next time it should be even better. Make sure to just make barely enough roux, otherwise it does come out with more of a grainy texture. One heaping tablespoon of butter and two of flour is more than enough...don't go hog wild with the flour otherwise you taste it and have to keep adding more and more liquid.

I heated my milk in the microwave first so it wouldn't take as long to thicken on top of the stove. text:
Have been looking for that perfect Mac and Cheese... I have tried several recipes.. Finally found the one!  I used about 12.5 oz just because that is what I had on hand.  Increased the flour to 3 full tbsps, increased the chedder to 3 cups and 1 cup of mozza (i love cheese)I read the reviews first and took some of their suggestions.  I added about a tsp of powdered mustard and onion powder.  The sauce was very runny, but one cooked, it was perfect.  I added the bread crumbs and paprika in the last 10 minutes.  If you like a lot of crunch, you could easily double that part of the recipe.  This recipe will be a repeat one for me!

userID:
3556574
Display Name:
Allan
isPro:
False

3

8
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1045065.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Use this recipe for a good base to start.  This recipe was too bland.  Next time I will use an additional cup of chedder cheese.  I think that may do it but not sure.  Next time I will add 1/2 teaspoon of salt because the cream sauce and noodles give a bland taste without additional salt.  This recipe doesn't state the size of cassarole dish.  For 1/2 box of noodles (8 oz) I used a 9" x 7" x 3"deep dish which worked O.K.  Do not, do not cook the noodles until done.  That will make too soft of noodles after baking.  I hate that at restaurants. Cook only 5 minutes or less instead of the 7 minutes stated on the box.  Use crushed cracker crumbs instead of bread.  They have a better texture and is easier.  All in all this recipe is not the finished produce. It needs some work but a good place to start.

I've made this twice now, and it is delicious. Unfortunately the second time I think I burned the roux a little beacuse it was left on the stove too long at too high of a heat before I added the milk, because in the end my cheese was like it had been melted in a microwave, not very saucy at all. It didn't even seep into the noodles when I put it on top, it just sat there! Frustrated me greatly, but it's still pretty good. But that was my own mistake, I'll just have to keep a closer eye on it next time.

I think this recipe turned out well. Based on other reviews I left out the parmesan because all I had was grated parmesan and I didnt want it to be gritty. I added a few tbsp of sour cream, salt, pepper, garlic powder, and ground mustard. I only used 2 cups of milk as well. I subbed the bread crumbs for ritz crackers since the exp date was near. Will def make again!

city:

country:
None
text:
I can not rate this as I did not follow all of the directions. The five stars is for my own version of this dish. However, here are my changes 2 c monterey jack/colbyjack cheese 1 c sharp cheddar 1 can evaporated milk and 1 cup whole milk .. I made the roux with the 2.5 T flour and the 1/4 c butter added the cheeses until melted then I add about 3T sugar and 1.5 T mustard . Pour this over 16 oz box of cooked(in salted water) elbow macaronis and then liberally sprinkle with lawry's season salt. Then I bake until just bubbly .. The additions I made are how I usually make my mac and cheese but I usually add velveeta cheese and forgot to buy some and did not feel like going back to the store. I needed a cheese sauce type of recipe to get the melted consistency of the velveeta. This worked out perfect and it was very good with no leftovers

This was absolutely delicious!  It was my first attempt at making "real" macaroni and cheese, and I'll never go back!

text:
This was a HUGE hit with my whole family!!! I did follow the advice on here and added 3 cups Colby jack cheese, 1 cup milk, 1 1/2 cups evaporated milk, 1/2 cup finely diced sweet onion, 2 cloves garlic, 1 /2 tsp. salt, pepper to taste, and used crushed Ritz crackers instead of the bread crumbs. I also omitted the Parmesan from the sauce and threw it on the top with the crackers. It was SO rich and divine!!! My pickiest eater even asked for seconds! Definite keeper in our house!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like my macaroni with a thick and creamy sauce, but this was a bit overload even for me. The problem wasn't that it was too thick, in fact I would prefer it even a bit thicker. I just felt it was simply too much sauce. It almost seemed like a thick cheese soup with a few noodles in it. Also, I didn't think the breadcrumbs needed the butter. Next time I'll use less milk and more noodles. I will also spread a bit more breadcrumbs on top. I used Italian breadcrumbs and I liked what it did to the flavor. Overall, I think this is a good foundation recipe to build on, but it definitely requires modifications to meet my taste.

text:
I made this tonight for my boy who just got his tonsils out.  Here are a couple of things that I noticed with this recipe.  First, you need a whole lb of pasta this makes a ton of sauce.  Next you need to salt the water 2T for a lb of pasta.  I used 3 cups of already shreaded cheese and 1 cup of fresh grated pram.  I used 2T of flour in the rou, but I think 3T would have been better.  I also used salt and pepper in the sauce.  I omitted the bread crumbs on top. It only took 15 minutes in the oven not the 30.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
I used some tips from others.  I did 1/2 cup evaporated milk, 1 cup of milk, 1/2 cup sour cream, 1/2 cup of half and half (mixed with the butter and flour).  I also used Mozzarella, Gorgonzola, Havarti and Extra Sharp Cheddar. I took my time like I was suppose to mixing constantly and adding in the liquids and cheese slow. It WAS AMAZING.  The gorgonzola gave it the kick some of the other reviews were lacking.  I also used the Panko Bread crumbs like suggested.  This was my first time making mac and cheese and what a success!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!  a friend gave me basically the same recipe a long time ago.  I have tweaked it a bit.  I sauté some mushrooms (usually any that are on sale at the grocery store), I also sauté some chopped onions and add it to the cheese sauce before I put the noodles in.  I find this gives it a little more texture that I'm looking for.  I also not only put cheddar cheese in the sauce but also put in Colby and for an extra bite I use pepper jack cheese.  It's the perfect combination to me.  If I have it I'll add some white truffle oil to the cheese sauce.  It adds to the richness.  Next time I make it I'm going to substitute half and half cream for half of the milk required and see how that turns out.

Everybody loved this! I didn't have any parmesan cheese, so I just used 3 cups of medium cheddar. I also used 5% light cream and a bit of evaporated milk instead of milk. Next time I will add Green onions and bacon to step it up a notch and give the dish some colour.

text:
I have made this at least 3 times. It is my "go to" mac and cheese and I'm asked for the recipe whenever I serve it. Yes, you panic at first when you see the amount of liquid, but it's exactly right. I have added dry mustard but don't taste much difference. For a super-rich, decadent version I use 1/2 and 1/2 for part of the milk. I always double the recipe and it perfectly fills a deep 13×9 baking pan.

text:
I baked it for only 15 mins and then let it sit for another 15-20 mins and it firmed up nicely. I also top mine with more cheese, bread crumbs and I mix in bacon, salt & pepper. I used a mix blend of cheese. I used 2 bags. 1.5 in the mix and the rest on top. It was delicious. If you find it too bland, do what I did and add some extra flavor such as salt, pepper, paprika, bacon, etc.

I add about 6 cups of cheese total for a double recipe. Found it to add some moisture and deliciousness. OH! and Try a few dashes of Franks Red Hot Sauce and a little mustard! None
text:
Great, great, great recipe. Don't think you're limited to just Parmesan and cheddar cheeses, either. I like to add in a little mozzarella, Monterrey jack, pepperjack, whatever I feel like, really.

Also, I like to mix it up by reducing the milk to 1 1/2 cups. using a cup of heavy whipping cream, and a tablespoon or so each of cream cheese and sour cream. You can play around bunch and it still comes out super creamy and delicious.

Lastly, Ritz crackers instead of breadcrumbs is fantastic (or a combination of both!)

text:
This is so good! I will say that it is probably more of a "southern" style recipe. I say this because it seems like in the South mac and cheese is very creamy. One moderation I would make is to add a little bit of salt before popping it in the oven. The paprika sprinkled on top produces a lot of flavor! Also the parmesan will make it a lottle grainy, so you may want to substitute another cheese.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with a few modifications...

My husband eats gluten-free, so I made it with gluten-free rotini (which I had on hand), and gluten-free flour for the roux.  I thought it would taste a little rice-ish, but it was just fine.

I shred my own cheese, so I used a block of cheddar cheese for that, and your standard Parmesan cheese.  I can't help but think that if I had actually had some shredded Parmesan on hand, it would've been a bit tastier.  The Parmesan seemed to get lost in the recipe.

I agree with the addition of mustard.  It gives it a nice tang that cuts through the ultra-cheesy flavor.

All in all?  A keeper.  I will be making this mac 'n cheese again!

text:
My family didn't really eat it.  I can pack it for leftovers and be ok, but they were right: The noodles were mushy ("cook according to package" - I did), and the sauce was grainy.  I think it was grainy because some of the bread crumbs sink into the sauce, which is really soupy pre-oven.  My husband wanted it creamier and less casserole-ish.  I did utilize the tip about adding some ground mustard, and stirred in some garlic powder as well (like 1/4 tsp).  Glad I did, or it would have been bland.

I will try this again with a lot of tweaks.

My men loved this easy recipe.  I wish I had seen the tip about 8 oz. of macaroni equaling 1 3/4 cups, before I cooked this. text:
I found this recipe Really helpful and when I made it, it turned out perfect! There was only one thing I changed and it was that I used 1 ½ c. Half and Half and 1 ½ c. Milk instead of just 3 cups of milk. But other than that it turned out very nice. I love to cook and I will highly recommend this recipe to Anyone that wished to make some good homemade Mac & Cheese. The bread crumbs gave it a nice crisp on the top but it wasn’t too overpowering. When I made this for my family, they kept going back for more and that night I wished I made multiple servings of this spectacular dish. I also didn’t mix the butter with the bread crumbs because I didn’t feel like it was necessary to add more fattening things when 2 c. of cheese was already added. I simply sprinkled the breadcrumbs over the top before baking!

text:
I've been making this recipe for our family for at least 6 years and we still love it!  I used to make it exactly as written and it was WONDERFUL!!!  Over the years, however, I decided to add a bit here and there to see how it would be.  I added 1 cup more cheddar, 1/4 cup more parm, 2 cups of shredded mozzarella, 1 tsp garlic powder, and 1/4 tsp dry mustard.  PERFECTION!!!  And to make it a meal instead of a side dish, I'll add in 1 pound of diced, cooked ham.  WE LOVE THIS!!

Happy cooking!!! :)

text:
I'm not a big mac & cheese lover so I'm probably a tougher critic than most.  This was OK, just like the note next to the 3 stars reads.  It was OK.  I accidentally added 2c 2% milk, not 3c.  After tasting, it was a good mistake.  I added 1t dry mustard & 1/2t salt, but it was still pretty bland.  Someone added a cup more cheese.  That could be all it needed.  The topping helps appearance, but that's about it.  'Could take it or leave it.  I used a 9x13 & it was on the shallow side so if you want more of the baked top, go for it.  I'll use a 9x11 next time.  I cooked a whole pound of elbows so there'll be another mac & cheese review in my future.  :/  ;D

text:
I followed this recipe except I didn't have any Parmesan so I substituted 1/2 cup of sharp cheddar cheese. It turned out a bit bland but we had it for dinner last night.

My bf added a little salt to his portion, we put it in the fridge overnight, we had it for lunch today and it was a bit dry after we zapped it in the microwave so my bf and I added milk to our portions.

Next time I will add a bit of salt and use Parmigiano-Reggiano ( the kind that comes in a block and you need to grate and not the kind in a container) and follow the recommendations of the other reviewers here. 

This is not a bad recipe, I will also follow the recommendations of the reviewers to make it more creamy. It's mac and cheese and it's not as if we eat this often. Think of this as a basic recipe to start from and then tweak it to your own taste.

text:
I don't usually leave reviews, but felt I had to after making this dish for my boyfriend last night. It turned out pretty bad - very mushy and grainy (almost curdled in texture) bc of the Parmesan cheese. I don't know why anyone hasn't mentioned this, but the macaroni should be undercooked before putting it in the oven, bc it continues to cook while in the oven for 30 min and ends up really mushy! The overall taste was pretty bland too, considering all the cheese in there (sharp cheeses, like old cheddar and parm, no less!). The bread crumbs were weird, nice and crunchy in parts but mostly just got absorbed into the body of the dish...would consider adding when casserole is almost cooked, for like the last 10 min to get an actual crispy crust. Very disappointing - would not make again :(

text:
This is pretty basic mac & cheese. But somehow it does turn out very creamy and delicious!! I think it might be the addition of the parmesan cheese. But it is truly yummy. For those looking for that missing little "something", try adding a dash of freshly grated nutmeg into your cheese sauce. It adds that subtle yet impressive 'wow' factor that some of you seem to be missing in this recipe.

userID:
5620108
Display Name:
Joanne
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been searching for an easy and delicious Mac & Cheese for a long time and found this one in my e-mail In-Box. It was SO good! I used all the exact amounts given, and tweaked in this way: I use skim milk in almost everything but knew this needed to be somewhat creamy, so I used 3/4 C Half-n-Half and the remaining 2 1/4 C Skim milk. I also added a little nutmeg to the sauce. For the cheese (which in my opinion is EVERYTHING in a Mac & Cheese) I used 1 Cup Extra Sharp Wisconsin Cheddar and 2 Cups Sharp NY Cheddar . The Parm was FRESH Reggiano - makes a huge difference. I was concerned because my sauce didnt seem to thicken enough (even after stirring a good 25 minutes) but I re-checked the video and saw the sauce was quite liquid so I went with it. It must thicken as it bakes. The other important characteristic is the TOPPING - I used Panko crumbs in place of bread crumbs and made sure they were nicely toasted. They added that wonderful cruch everyone loves on a M&C. Great recipe and great website.

text:
I made this last night and I have to say that is was, unfortunately, really bland. I did add dry mustard powder, but it was not enough to add any flavor. This dish definitely needs some salt and some other spices, otherwise it is incredibly bland. Even my husband - who loves most homemade Mac and Cheese recipes I've tried, only had a few bites due to it lacking flavor. So if you make this, make sure and add some salt & other spices you like (and a pinch of salt, which is what I added, won't do it).

text:
Great, easy recipe. This is the mac'n cheese I always wanted! Very cheesy and creamy. As Julie stated, it looked a bit runny when I poured the sauce over the macaroni, but it firmed up as it baked. I used buttered Panko breadcrumbs which workwd well. Also added just a touch of garlic salt, 2 1/2 cups of milk and a small can of evaporated milk instead of 3 cups of milk (also a tsp of Dijon mustard for some additional tanginess). This is a total keeper!

text:
Great method. I had to give only 4 stars bc i used 16oz of pasta, only 2.5 cups of milk, and I also added a pinch of paprika. I used Cabot seriously sharp white cheddar & Kraft white American singles. Mine turned out exactly as I imagined. I didn't want to add any garlic, mustard or anything like that; I agree with a previous poster that the cheese should be the star here. Great process, and it baked to perfection with a beautiful golden crust. TIPS: if you're not gonna add any spices, salt the water for pasta & use salted butter. Make your roux and cheese sauce on med-low heat.

I made this recipe for my granddaughter's 5th birthday dinner.  I used the variations mentioned by others: evaporated milk and sour cream along with milk to create a creamy sauce. I added mustard as suggested and, for additional flavor, added a half pound of cooked and crumbled bacon. I wanted to use good cheeses so decided on 1 cup of white Cheddar, and 1 cup of smoked Gruyere along with shaved Parmesan. I did use panko on the top. The smoked Gruyere was a good combination with the bacon and this was a hit! I will definitely make this again.

country:
None
text:
The first time I made this recipe, I followed the directions exactly and was very pleased! It was rich and flavorful, but the sauce was not as creamy as I would have liked after baking. The second time around I used 12 oz of fat free evaporated milk and 12 oz of regular fat free milk because other users recommended it for a creamier sauce. The sauce was also taking a super long time to thicken so I used cornstarch to speed things up. I also added extra cheese, and used a mix of aged cheddar, gruyere, and parmesan. I added ground mustard, onion and garlic powders, and some white pepper for extra flavor. This is a great recipe to play around with-- as long as you follow the basic directions you can really add whatever flavors you like. Thank you for sharing!

Made a couple of additions to kick up the flavor: used 1/2 cheddar, 1/2 double gloucester w/chives as the main cheeses. Added a couple dashes of garlic powder, onion powder, white pepper and chili powder to the milk/cheese mixture which gave it extra taste. Topped with 1/2 breadcrumbs & 1/2 panko for more crunch. Oh, and used campanelle pasta, which is what I had in the cupboard. Husband loved it. Delicious, quick, easy, homey meal (NOT low in fat, which is the whole point of mac and cheese!)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I combined this recipe with another I found online and tweaked it a bit. This version is definitely not for someone counting calories. I used a full stick of butter and three large spoonful’s of flour for the roux, I used 1.5 cup heavy cream and 1.5 cup milk as well as the 2 cup grated sharp cheddar cheese and .5 cup grated parmesan for the sauce. I used 16oz box of cavatappi for the macaroni. I added a .25 cup of mixed fresh herbs, a combination of parsley, tarragon, rosemary and chives. Also a .25 cup chopped green onion, 4 strips of cooked bacon also chopped up, I pored the cheese sauce over everything and mixed into a casserole dish. I cooked 1lb of steak tips marinated in steakhouse sauce with rosemary, cut them into smaller pieces and stuffed them into the mac and cheese. I used crushed ritz crackers and butter for the crust over the top and bakes for 20min at 350 degree.

text:
I gave it 4 stars, because I made some changes to the recipe.   I followed the advice of some other posters.   Here are the changes I made:
added 8 oz. Mont. Jack cheese and 2 cups of cheddar, 1 cup milk, 1 1/2 cups evaporated milk, generous sprinkling of garlic powder and onion powder, 1 /2 tsp. salt, pepper to taste, plus I added 1/2 block of cream cheese.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for ten people, aged 1 year to 58 and everyone except for one (broccoli hater) loved it. I took this basic recipe and added to it though - while adding the milk to the roux I included garlic pepper, garlic and onion powder, celery seed and white pepper to taste. I had also already cut up fresh chives and dill to add, and had fresh broccoli steaming to add to the cheese sauce.   I too was afraid of there being too much sauce. I used a half a cup less milk than suggested for the larger serving and accidentally filled the baking dish completely full, with still about a cup and a half extra sauce (now in the fridge). It boiled up a bit but did not boil over, and the texture came out perfect!   My older sister, whom I look up to for cooking, praised it --- and that's the best sign right there.

text:
I'll reiterate what others have said: this is a very good base recipe, but really needs something else. I followed the recipe exactly, other than substituting whole wheat zoo-shaped pasta for macaroni. I also thought salt was lacking, so I added about 1/2-1 tsp. BUT it needs more. I'll make it again, but try adding more salt, maybe some ground mustard, and doing half-cheddar, half smoked gouda because this is really, really BLAND. The texture was okay, a bit clumpy/cottage cheesey in the end, but I think that's what happens when you don't use velveeta. On the bright side, it has 94% of your daily calcium... (great for preggies and toddlers who aren't worried about gaining weight!)

text:
Awsome recipe !  I used the recipe as a guide and used 1 10oz stick of Cracker Barrel extra sharp white, 1 1/4 cup- reggiano and 1 1/2 cup shredded mozz. To the base sauce I added a good dash of Colemans dry mustard, a few shakes onion powder, garlic powder and a hefty dose of parsley flakes. Finishing the sauce I added 6 slices chopped crisp bacon. A GREAT recipe to get creative with, the possibilities are endless!!!!!!!!!

I was glad to see that I had everything on hand for this, that is the main reason why I picked it over some similar recipes. One thing about the way it printed out it that you read the ingredients from left to right and then down to the next row. I didn't realize this and accidently used 1/4 c butter for the roux instead of the few tbsp it was supposed to be. I'm not sure how this affected the results. The texture was fine but like others have said it was a bit bland, even after adding salt, pepper, and garlic powder to the cheese sauce. I did not brown the breadcrumbs because of a lack of time and I didn't want to use another 1/4 butter, too much fat!  To help with the blandness I added some bacon salt after cooking. This is a wonderful, fat free, kosher, low sodium, and vegan seasoning that really tastes just like bacon.  This did just the trick and it tasted great.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-03-08T19:16:33.667

text:
I made some changes that I thought would help with the blandness some people mentioned. To the cheese sauce, I added a little bit of garlic powder, seasoned salt, and nutmeg. I added 1/2 cup sour cream for even more creaminess, and I also added 1 T of yellow mustard. It gives that tang that I want with cheese. Other than that, I followed the instructions, and it was delicious! It does seem like too much sauce, but as others said, it's perfect when it's done!

text:
I saute chopped onions, add dry powdered mustard, salt and pepper before I add the flour. Then add milk and heat and stir, adding lots and lots of grated old cheddar cheese,stir till all cheese is melted keeping the sauce fairly thin as it will thicken after the macaroni is added and baked. Top with buttered cracker crumbs and bake till bubbly and lightly browned. I have used this recipe forever.

text:
This recipe is easy, but I agree with other reviewers who think it is a bit bland.  I will make this again, but I will be sure to use more flavorful cheeses and/or herbs and spices of some sort.  Those who have said that the sauce thickens once in the oven were right, I could see where it could become too dry.  I might cut back a bit on the oven time or slightly reduce the temperature.  I think this is a good base recipe for homemade macaroni and cheese, but it definitely needs a few alterations.

Geeat Mac n Cheese for kids.  Mild flavors and creamy sauce!  I used italian breadcrumbs to add a little flavor and also used shells rather than macaroni (shells hold the sauce!)  Make sure to FULLY melt the cheese in the cause before pouring it over.

text:
I LOVED this recipe!  I tend to be picky about my mac and cheese, and this one was awesome.  It reminded me a lot of the macaroni and cheese served at a local steakhouse, McKendricks, that is my favorite.
For the 3 cups milk, I used whole milk (I only use whole for cooking) to give it a richer taste.
Also, I used 1 sleeve of ritz crackers and crumbled them for the top, to give it a little more crunch.
My mother even borrowed the recipe for our Thanksgiving instead of her usual mac and cheese casserole!  It was a big hit!

I made this recipe pretty much as written, only I used 1/2 sharp cheddar, 1/2 marble cheddar (instead of only cheddar).

Loved it!  I agree, you must take the extra time with the sauce to prevent clumping.  

It was a bit thick and dry when reheated the next day, but still yummy.  (I would rate 4 1/2 stars because of this).  Next time I'll make adjustments to try to avoid this.

Personally, I like bread crumb topping but I only add it for the last 15 min or so of baking.  This recipe is just as good without it.

text:
By far the best macaroni and cheese I have ever had! I used skim milk to cut down on some of the fat/calories so I could use more cheese than what was called for! I sprinkled a little Romano cheese on top as soon as I took it out of the oven. I was out of elbow macaroni so I used Radiatore instead. This meal is good for a side dish or for the entree.

text:
My 13 year old made this recipe with my help. We followed the recipe exactly but did forget to add the paprika at the end. This was not the best homemade mac n cheese I've had (also not the worst). I felt bad for my daughter because this was her first attempt at really cooking from scratch. Even she commented that there was something off about it. Personally,  I think it was too much cheddar and it sat really heavy in my stomach.  I think a blend of different cheeses would have tasted better. I would not make this again. We made enough for leftovers,  and I kinda wish we hadn't.

country:

text:
I did add some spices, but other than that, followed the recipe as written.  I've been searching for a mac & cheese that isn't gummy and dry - and this one is a keeper.  It seems like a lot of liquid for the amount of macaroni, but trust me, it isn't.  Great consistency.  My only negative comment is one that others have made - the parmesan cheese makes the sauce a bit grainy - I might leave it out next time for that reason.  But otherwise, this was great.  (I added a dash of cayenne pepper, nutmeg, thyme and worcestershire sauce, plus a tsp of dijon mustard).

text:
This was absolutely amazing! I did a couple things differently though to make it a bit spicy and less bland. I substituted the cheese for 1 cup pepper jack, 1 cup Colby jack, and a half cup of cottage cheese. I also added a southwest blend of spices (half of: www.foodnetwork.com - emerils southwest seasoning) to the cheese. I used only 2 cups of milk instead of 3. I also added some crispy bacon bits, tomatoes, and green onions on top before I put it in the oven.

I was out of flour from making pie crust for an apple pie yesterday so I used just a sprinkle of corn starch to help thicken the cheese sauce. Overall this is a super easy side dish for a dinner of 4-8 people. I made steaks on our grill and some sautéed green beans to go along with the Mac and cheese. Happy full family of 4, 2 being very picky eaters!

text:
I added some diced ham steaks that I’d sautéed first in olive oil and butter. I’d like to have had something green like peas. 

The ham gave the fish some saltiness, so it was well seasoned. The paprika on top was meaningless. I probably could have used better bread crumbs. Also could have substituted some gruyere for some of the cheddar, to give it a little more bite. 

All in all, very tasty and a crowd pleaser.

text:
I doubled the recipe so I could pour it into a crockpot to bring to a fundraiser, and it was perfect. After reading the number of reviews that mentioned how much liquid there was, I thought this would be perfect for keeping the noodles from drying out in the crockpot and it was as it definitely thickens up as it sits (even before turning on the crockpot). I followed other reviewers suggestions and substituted evaporated milk for half the milk. I also added a 1/2 cup of sour cream.

Display Name:
quaint

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4.5 stars. Like others, I made modifications based on the reviews. I subbed half of the milk with evaporated milk and heavily salted the pasta water. I used grated romano instead of parmesan.  Poured in about 12 oz worth of shell pasta instead of 8. I also seasoned with garlic salt, lots of pepper, a few pinches of red pepper flakes, and parsley. I used the Irish herbed butter, which added some more flavor The breadcrumbs came out crunchy, just make sure you toast them long enough/in high enough heat. Mine didn't seem too runny (before I baked), and it had the perfect consistency when done.

A good base recipe to throw in your own modifications. It does have a rather mild flavor, but still had enough to keep my taste buds pleased. Bacon and/or something with a little spice (maybe jalapeno?) would give it a good kick if you're looking for something extra.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-11-23T02:02:26.61
helpfulCount:
0

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I highly recommend reading all of the reviews before making this. I'm a seasoned Cook and I should have known better with regard to how much pasta to use. 8 oz is not equal to an 8 oz cup it's equal to one and three quarter cups. also, I highly recommend using a variety of milks including half and half and evaporated milk which I only used half and half so it came out very rich and not extremely tasty until I salted it. it's a great recipe to play around with. Definitely read all the reviews. adding a little hot sauce makes all the difference in the world too.

text:
Followed recipe to a  T.  Very bland.  I should have known.  
3 Cups of milk seemed to much and diluted the cheesey taste-- and most recipes add a dash of mustard powder, or garlic powder, or diced onion.  This was pretty tasteless.    If you stop at this recipe, I suggest you keep looking.  I've just read other reviews  and theirs are similar to mine.  I will repeat what a few reviewers said:  DO NOT USE THIS RECIPE.  Wast of time and ingredients.  We ate 2 bowlfuls,  the dog at a little, and we're tossing the rest.   Others who changed the recipe with evaporated milk said it was creamy.  I followed the recipe to a T, and it was NOT creamy, and too bland to enjoy.  Is there a way to get a recipe off All Recipe so others won't waste time and ingredients?

This recipe came out great.  The liqiudy part of  sauce thickened in oven. I used Italian breadcrumbs sautéed in a cast iron skillet and one stick of butter, then topped pasta mix with it and then topped with crumbled bacon pieces. Not bland at all, used yellow extra sharp, white extra sharp,  parmesan, and Monterey Jack.   Needs no salt due to the saltiness of bacon, breadcrumbs, cheeses, and pasta cooked with plenty of sea salt in water.

text:
It is better than the box... but has some flaws.  First a roux is normally 1:1... it should have been stated the roux will be loose and so will the cheese sauce... before baking.  Also, 2 cups of cheddar cheese is not enough... needs at least 1 more cup.  Butter was listed twice ingredients, but not indicated one for sauce and one for topping... was confusing.  Finally I used Panko (plain) breadcrumbs rather than regular... was great... but butter/panko quantity should be doubled.  In the reviews I saw a suggestion of Half & Half rather than milk... sounds yummy... perhaps next time!

text:
The fact that we can't do half-stars is unfair; this is better than a 3-star meal, but not quite a four-star one. It's a really great "beginners' mac and cheese"- if you've never made a homemade mac and cheese before and you want a recipe on "easy mode," this one is for you! But it did seem to me to be a little plain. It's just cheesy enough, but it could use something else extra. The paprika didn't add much even though I added in more than just a pinch, and I wanted something stronger to season it and give it a real punch of flavor. Still, though, it was easy and tasty, and makes plenty of leftovers. So I can't really complain!

text:
I was excited about this recipe as it got pretty good reviews. But I found it very bland, even though I followed the recipe exactly.  It might be OK for little kids, but for adults who like a bit of taste, I would add some chopped white onion, and some diced tomato meat (without the inside juice & seeds). Also a small amount of black pepper, kosher salt into the cheese mix.  Cheese and onion are always favorities with grilled cheese, so I think this would add some good flavor.  I also would try a 1/2 t. dry mustard and a few dashes of nutmeg. Good luck!

After reading reviews made the following changes:  used 1 12 oz. can evaporated milk and 12 oz. of milk, and used 16 oz. of large elbow macaroni.  Be sure to use freshly grated parmesan not the stuff in the jar!  Next time I'll use only 1/4 cup of breadcrumbs 1/2 cup was too much.  The result was the best mac n cheese I've ever made and I'll use this recipe again and again!!  My husband requested diced ham as an addition next time and I'll try it for him....but no other changes the recipe is PERFECT ?

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is pretty good, I've made it a couple time, omitting the bread crumbs because they simply don't fit my idea of a smooth creamy M&C. I read many of the one star reviews and came to the conclusion that each and every one of them probably are lacking enough background cooking techniques that simply following the recipe to the letter can't possibly result in a quality meal that's going to please. They each stated similar blandness and runniness as the problem, assuming that this recipe can accommodate subtle changes and variables that need to be already well learned to actually accomplish the desired end results. And with that, I mean to express that the first stage of cooking a mac and cheese sauce requires a tasty roux and it needs a bit of time to develop a flavor. Simply melting butter, adding and mixing the flour, blending and immediately dumping the cheese in means that the resulting sauce is going to be bad, without fail. Adding a pinch or dried mustard is the main thing I don't think I saw in the recipe. Additionally adding another variety of cheese is essential. Plain cheddar is what makes this actual recipe only 3-4 stars worthy, but it's a good platform to start from.
Review:
Rating:
5

2018-01-13T13:06:20.037

text:
It’s a good recipe. Came out pretty creamy except I kinda cleaned out my pantry of all the elbows in it and had to make more sauce. I added half and half until it was pretty thin.  Probably could have even been even thinner, but it looked like I was reaching the limit of my 6 qt. Casserole, so I stopped adding the milk.  I threw a handful of ham in it, used up some guyeure I found in the fridge along with a block of velveeta, a tiny bit of blue I had, and then the rest sharp cheddar. The Dijon is a nice touch, really set of the dish. I served it up to the twenty somethings that live with me for New Years Day. They really liked it. I did too.

text:
Making a correct roux is extremely important.  Watch a youtube video, if you need to.  Mine came out nice and firm.  Also, 8 oz. of elbow macaroni is equal to about 2 cups, so be careful.  I gave it four stars, because I needed to add a good amount of salt, mustard powder, and Worcestershire sauce to give it flavor.  I also recommend using fresh grated Parmesan cheese.

Yum!! I made some changes due to what I had on hand and based on other reviews. I made this with Colby jack cheese and Parmesan, used 2 cups evaporated milk and 1 cup 2% milk, and used cornstarch instead of flour. I will make again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4540459.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Will definitely be making this again! I'm a Mac & Cheese fiend. I doubled the recipe because I couldn't find an 8oz box of elbow macaroni.

Changes I made:
2 -- 8oz bags of Sharp Cheddar Cheese
1--8oz bag of Italian five Cheese Blend
2--8oz bags of  Mexican Four Cheese (I know sounds weird but I'm telling you it blends very well!)

Added --Garlic powder, 1 tbs of mustard powder, & black pepper to your liking. I eyed it on the garlic powder, but it was probably about 1 tbs, add enough to where you can slightly taste the garlic. Add these spices to the cheese! 

I used Italian bread crumbs because it's what I had on hand but it tastes fireeee. Also I added the bread crumbs without mixing them with butter since the cheese has enough moisture for it.

All in all I love this recipe with my changes.

text:
It was good but I wish the recipe had called for some basic salt and pepper.  It definitely needs it and I saw on another mac and chess recipe to add it after the milk.  Also,I covered mine up with foil and stuck in fridge, then popped in over with foil on.  The browned breadcrumb topping was soggy 30 min later.  I believe it is supposed to be crunchy.  Note to self, to take the aluminum foil off for last 10 minutes to get the topping crunchy.   My kids really liked it.

Since we don't have sharp cheddar in canada I can't figure out what cheese is best to use but went with medium.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is almost exactly how I make Mac n cheese (except I'm lazy and skip baking/ breadcrumbs and just use a lil more flour quite often). To the bland comments- sharp vs mild cheddar makes a big difference. This is a great base, but try cooking some minced onions in the butter, and adding a bit of nutmeg (just a little, ¼ tsp ish), dry mustard and fresh ground pepper. This shouldn't be grainy. If it is, make sure to brown the roux (when it smells heavenly on its own it's ready) and add the milk in batches and really stir. Cold milk + hot roux shouldnt have any problems. Also, do NOT use pre-grated parm. The Kraft Shakey cheese stuff is more cellulose than cheese and does not have the same taste as parm and will not melt smoothly. If that's all the parm you have, sub in some other type of cheese you like and have on hand. (the flakes of parm should work fine, but I've never used them. it's usually cheaper to just get the block)

userID:

Display Name:
sanderella

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A good recipe, but if you want a bit more flavorful result, try what I did. I added 1 1/2 tsp dried mustard a tsp dijon mustard to the roux along with a Tbsp minced garlic and 2 tsp Worchestershire, with a couple generous pinches black pepper and a pinch of red pepper flakes. It won't be spicy.
For the wet ingredients I used 1 cup of sour cream, 1 cup cottage cheese, 1 1/2 cup half and half. ( use low fat dairy if you want butI feel it does take away from the richness ) I had 2 8oz blocks of Colby Jack cheese so I grated those to mix into the roux ( pre shredded cheeses are not as flavorful and it tend to be dry ) I like gooey cheese ! I used Panko crumbs right out of the bag to sprinkle on top before I put it in the oven. Don't worry if it looked too runny, it will be fine ! Last few minutes of baking I turn the broiler on to toast the Panko topping until golden brown. OMG SO GOOD !

I was gonna give 4 stars but with the recommendations of a couple of people and a bit of my own it turned out better than any recipe for Mac n Cheese that I've ever made.I subbed a cup of the milk with chick broth added dry mustard, garlic and onion powder then used half the cheddar with apple wood smoked greyier(check the spelling) and 1/4 parm cheeses then instead of browning the bread crumbs I just broiled at the end and this turned out so great. The most creamy and delicious Mac n Cheese ever. Like one person said a heart attack type of dish but dang it was worth it

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it just the other night at a sleepover with my friend and since we did not have milk, we substituted it with cream to make the roux.
Since cream is of course much thicker than milk I added a very little amount of water to thin out the sauce. 
Also, we didn't have breadcrumbs but I did something weird to add the extra later of crunch. It was a chicken and sweet corn Mac n cheese, so I had also stir fried some chicken and corn with onion and garlic in a pan before adding it to the baking dish.
I let bits of the stir fry to stick to the pan(it had assumed the texture of crackling) and scraped it off once the chicken was done. I sprinkled this scraped off crackling over the macaroni and cheese before popping it in the oven. Turned out just fine.

SALT THE PASTA WATER, FOLKS!

text:
i thought this recipie was wonderful....i used a smoked applewood cheddar  (highly recommend) and parm, with some montreal smoked meat. i admit that i too panicked and added extra flour to the sauce before i baked it (mistake).  i should have read the reviews  first.  it was tasty but a little too thick, which was my fault.   i find that the parm made it a little gritty also. not sure if it was because i used frozen pregrated parm or not?  next time i will add a different cheese other than parm. i can see how some people might have thought it was bland if they didn t use sharp/stronger cheeses.  i would definately make this again.  it is a great stand alone recipie or base to be more creative.  next time pulled pork,gouda and applewood smoked cheddar....yum!

Pretty sure this is served in Heaven because it sure does tastes like Heaven. It's so creamy! I've never made Mac-N-Cheese from scratch so I can't compare it to any other recipes and I can't find a reason to try any other recipes. THIS is exactly what I was craving in my mouth. I did however use Ritz crackers instead of breadcrumbs. I also used  2 1/2 cups of heavy whipping cream with a 1/2 cup of water instead of 3 cups of milk because that's what I had in the fridge. I served this delectable dish with a mountain of Broccoli to clear my  conscience  
I can say with no doubt that I will never buy the blue box  Mac & cheese ever again.

text:
This is the closest example of what my grandmother used to make before she died 27 years ago. I have been looking ever since, this recipe nails it. I did not have sharp cheddar at hand, but old white cheddar was just as good. The only change I made was adding white pepper to the cheese mixture after tasting before pouring onto the pasta. I too was concerned for the runniness of the sauce, but it does thicken nicely as moisture evaporates during cooking. I guaranty this will be doubled or tripled for a large dinner.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I usually make mac n cheese with pepper jack but I wanted something comforting/old fashioned. This is my old recipe, by and large. Those who found the texture gritty...you are heating the cheese sauce way too high and the proteins are separating. Low and slow to get that creamy texture. I always sauté 1-2T finely chopped onions and add Worcestershire sauce for some punch. Concur with the dried mustard but put a tiny bit of nutmeg in the dish...not much. It brings out the flavour of the cheese. If it is a little too sour...cheat and put 1/4tsp of sugar in the sauce. But a good solid recipe.
Review:

5

text:
Only gave 4 stars as I changed it as per previous review suggestions. Very yummy. I made with a variety of cheese that we had in the house. As per other reviews, I used 1 can evaporated milk, 1/2c sour cream,  and topped up with milk to make 3 cups. I sautéed garlic and onions in the butter before making the roux. I added cumin and mustard seed  while the sauce was cooking (I had no paprika).  It does look like way too much sauce when you pour it over the macaroni and it looks very runny. It works out OK. I found my noodles over cooked, so I am going to try baking them from raw next time .

K.B.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Even though my family enjoyed this Mac 'n cheese, I'm only giving this recipe 4 stars because I feel it needs some changes. First, the title should read "Baked...". I hadn't realized it was a baked dish until I started making it, so I had to make some changes with the amount of milk/sauce. Also, I would substitute the milk with half and half or even heavy cream, or a combination of these three, according to your preference. Also, instead of Parmesan, I would add some Gouda. Gouda gives this a rich, smoky flavor that really tastes amazing. The parm gave it a slightly grainy texture. Perhaps baking it would give a different result. Another tip: make sure the pasta is a bit undercooked before baking it, so it doesn't turn out too soft.
Review:

4

Great Dish, a few tips/changes I would suggest. 1) The Milk/cheese will seem too runny. It's not, it will bake nicely into the noodles. 2) Add Onion to the butter before adding flour. 3) Add some Dry Mustard 4) Add frozen peas (sounds weird but it's delicious) 5) Only half cook the pasta as it will definitely continue to cook in the oven while baking.

userID:
15182623
Display Name:
pickyeater
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
7
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! This was easy to make and fun to make. I did Japanese panko instead of bread crumbs (which actually made a big difference). I used the full 1/2 cup of crumbs, and there was not too much. It was crunchy and delicious and I think it would probably work better than regular bread crumbs.

I followed the recipe otherwise, and it turned out great! It wasn't too bland or lumpy, and I'm surprised that it tastes so good, while the ingredients are healthy for mac & cheese. 

At first I thought the sauce was too runny to bake within 30 minutes, but it turned out perfectly! 

It served my four-person (two adults, two kids) family, and we actually had 2/3 left, so if you don't feel like having leftovers you could possibly divide the recipe in half.

Don't eat this before going anywhere important... it's heavy and will make you a bit sleepy! If you eat too much, it will sit like a rock in your stomach. 

I will definitely make this again, and I definitely recommend this.
Review:

5

text:
Had to make a few changes due to what was available, tripled the batch. Added a tsp of mustard powder, salted the boiling noodles, used 8 C dehydrated milk reconstituted, used 1/2 C Monterey jack cheese, a 32 oz bar of processed cheddar cheese (similar to velveeta, accept it's natural) and 3/4 C Grated parmesan, also used whole wheat flour for the roux. Even the Hubby ate it...and he hates mac& cheese. I stuffed bell peppers with it and topped with bacon pieces.

I made this without reading any reviews first. Right away, I doubled the recipe because I had a 16oz package of elbow macaroni. I had no problems with making the roux and my cheese sauce turned out smooth, thick and creamy. I was super worried about having too much sauce, and didn't pour all of in the dish. My son loved it and my husband did, too, although he said he would have liked a cruncher topping. I thought it was just right.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it twice! Original recipe first, the breadcrumbs were bit of a distraction from the core texture of the dish. RE-make; add 1 cup of pepper jack, 4 oz of diced green chilies (mild,) 1/2 teaspoon dry mustard, Cut 1/2 cup of Parmesan down to 1/8 cup. Before placing in oven sprinkle more Parmesan lightly on top, then sprinkle equal amount of breadcrumbs (uncooked) on top the Parm. As the macaroni gets mixed be sure to add S/P... Taste and adjust S/P before applying Parm/Breadcrumb topping. (TIP: heavier on pepper than salt.)

text:
My 1st ever attempt at making homemade mac & cheese, and I am so very glad I chose this recipe!  I did take the recommendations of others and I used 1 1/2 cups of milk and 1 1/2 cups of evaporated milk.  I also eliminated the grated parmesan cheese and decided to use 1 1/2 cups of Colby  Monterey Jack instead.  This turned out simple amazing.  I also took the suggestions about adding some seasoning to the cheese mixture while it was cooking.  I used garlic powder and onion powder, not much I would say about a 1/2 teaspoon of each.  Something happened when I put the browned bread crumbs onto of the dish and in the end I had to scrape the topping off because that part did not turn out.  However, this did not effect the taste of the dish at all.
This recipe is definitely going in the recipe book and I will be making it again.

text:
It was pretty good.  Easy too.  Hubby actually loved it,  I was impressed, but not falling over in love.  I used half cream and half milk.  As a bunch of other reviews said,  there seemed to be waaaay too much sauce,  but it all fixed itself in the oven.  Don't freak out,  it's supposed to look like soup before the oven part.  I didn't have breadcrumbs so I crushed up Ritz crackers,  wasn't too crazy about the topping..  Also I used half sharp cheddar,  some motazarella, and a colby  jack blend..  It was good.  Next time I'm totally going to add bacon and see what that does to it,  I bet then it'd be a 5 star in my book!

text:
Made  this  almost as directed; made a few changes based on what I had - 2% milk , whole wheat elbow macaroni, and fat free cheddar. I also seasoned to taste with salt, pepper and Lowry's seasoning salt. Granted, I'm no mac-and-cheese connoisseur like some reviewers here seem to be, but it tasted fan-freakin-tastic to me and my kiddos. Loads better than the processed boxed kind, and I felt better about serving it to my children too, even if it's not exactly waistline friendly. In short, comforting and delish as-is, no major changes necessary. At least not to my unrefined mac-and-cheese palate. ;)

region:

country:

text:
I have not made this but I cook enough to know it is pretty decent.  One suggestion - do not buy cheap parmesan or this will be too salty.  I don't mean you have to buy the most expensive either.  Just a good quality.  Romano seems to be less salty to me.  

Finally, I cook the macaroni about 2 minutes less because you're going to be baking it for 30 minutes.  Agree with others dry mustard is a very good addition.
Review:
Rating:

text:
This a basic recipe for mac and cheese. I use 3 tbl. flour , 3 tbl. butter to 2 1/4 c. milk for the white sauce.  I add whatever cheese I have: Cheddar, a little pepper jack  adds a little zip and a couple of slices of American cheese makes it smoother.  I also use prepared mustard. (about 1tsp) This never lasts long in our house.

This is a good basic recipe. I didn't add crumbs until the last moments of baking.  Also, it is bland if you don't add your favorite seasonings. On a different occasion, I used Asiago cheese w/rosemary and garlic and plain cheddar instead of sharp.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe but made it my own way! I made it for 8 people so I used these as my measurements:

1 pound elbow pasta
2 cup sharp cheddar (pre shredded)
2.5 cups 2% milk
1/2 cup sour cream
1/2 cup butter
1/4 cup flour (white)
1 packet of bacon hand shredded (pre cooked)
1 teaspoon frank's red hot
1 tablespoon of spices (family recipe)
1 teaspoon paprika

I made this very different from the main recipe posted but everyone loved it, wanted seconds and raved about it! I even surprised myself and cannot wait to have more for dinner tonight. Amazing!

userID:
8252238
Display Name:
Veronica Brickhouse
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6775725.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made homemade mac & cheese for as long as I can remember (I got it from my mama). I only gave this one 3 stars because it was missing a few things that give it it's 'yummy', 'go for seconds' taste. I have always used a teaspoon of prepared mustard (I know, shocker!) it is a stronger flavor plus you can adjust the strength as you cook the sauce. Also, please use salt, pepper and any other seasoning you love in the sauce. Personally, I love a little Garlic and Onion Powder taste to my mac & cheese. Add all these seasonings BEFORE you add the cheeses, that way you can get the perfect flavoring for your sauce!  Good luck, and enjoy!

Display Name:
galdra
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, after reading reviews, I took the recipe as listed here (a good base) and then doctored it up.  It was amazing!  I used an Italian truffle cheddar, and replaced the parm with a mix of romano and blue cheese.  As the milk was heating, I added (to the cooking milk mix)  smoked paprika, dried mustard, black pepper, and a smoked sea salt - and tasted the blend as I was cooking (very important).  When I added the cheeses, it didn't need anything else.   I then cut up a pre-cooked ham steak (breakfast size) into chunks, mixed that with the macaroni, then poured the cheesy mix over.  I used crushed garlic croutons instead of the breadcrumbs on top (sautéed in butter prior to topping) and sprinkled a titch more smoked paprika over the top.  It smelled phenomenal as it baked - and tasted even better.   I highly recommend that you taste as you go.

text:
It's a pretty good backbone for macaroni and cheese, but you definitely have to add some more to it. I added some garlic, basil, and pepper to it while baking, and after it was done, I quickly realized that it needed some salt (or perhaps another sauce/condiment to tie it all together): it was a little bland. That might be because of the fact that I didn't use as much Parmesan as the recipe had asked for. I'd still bake it again, though (with additions, of course).

text:
To make this less boring, use cream cheese and sour cream instead of 1 cup of the milk and add an extra cup of EXTRA SHARP cheddar cheese. Also don't forget a dash of garlic powder and a tsp of freshly ground mustard seed in the 'sauce'. If this isn't good enough for you, you don't know mac & cheese.

text:
Like others have said, it didn't have enough flavor. So this time I used 12 oz box of GF Penne Pasta, 1/2 cup Parmesan, 1/2 cup jalepeno jack, and 3 cups of sharp cheddar.  Also used one can of evaporated milk for part of the milk.  Added some ground mustard and garlic powder.  I also didn't use any bread crumbs.  But all in all I really like the base recipe and it gave me times and temperatures.
