photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Creamy! My 1st time making homemade Mac. Others I have tried were dry and crumbly- THIS was thick and creamy and moiste- even w the bread crumbs. It would have been alittle bland w/out my addition of salt, pepper, and onion powder- season your bread crumbs too or use crushed Ritz. My husband LOVED this and ate 3 helpings. The kids however were not as into it. My 8yr old ate it and likes it ok but the 3 year old- who requested this dish!- took 2 bites and said he prefers Kraft. Whatever, he's picky. I liked it. Also, for your rue, 4 TBS of butter needs 4TBS of flour. Cook that for a few minutes then very very gradually wisk in the milk. Cook that down for 3 min before adding your cheese in handfuls- grate it yourself, the pre-grated  won't melt as well.

Display Name:
Beverly El Dorado
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3605000.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a classic baked Macaroni  and Cheese recipe, which is a relief from all the glamour mac and cheese recipes that are trendy today. You have to have the patience to make a roux, and then slowly add the milk and cheese, which can be hard to do if you are a new cook, or are in a rush. It's the sort of thing best done while chatting with a friend or listening to a podcast. 

The only change I made was to add a little garlic salt to the cheese sauce and not brown the bread crumbs in butter - it's fatty enough already, and browned bread crumbs can be a pain. 

I also went really easy on the bread crumbs - just a dusting  across the top - and then did a similar dusting of paprika. It turned out pretty, and very good.
Review:
Rating:
1

2016-05-24T21:17:08.723

text:
Good recipe. My own tips for first timers. Don't wait for cheese sauce to thicken at all. When cheese is 3/4 melted, it's ready. Don't add salt to sauce, especially if adding meat. Let cook, then salt to taste. I'd skip the paprika.  Add one small hot dog dash of mustard.

text:
I used instead:
 ~1/2C mozzarella
~1/2C Sharp Cheddar 
~1/4C Parmeseano Reggiano
1/4lbs Pancetta chopped and fried

And, oh my, it was amazing :-) definitely a great base recipe!

*also, use whisk to combine flour/butter for 2mins, then slowly add milk. Switch to a wooden spoon/scraper and stir in a figure-8 motion until the milk mixture sticks to the back of the spoon enough for you to run your finger through and leave a gap. May seem runny, but it will cook in the oven :-)

I like when people make changes. Gives me ideas to substitute when I don't have all the ingredients. I only had 2 cups of skim milk but I had 3/4 c of heavy cream.  Didn't have sharp cheddar but had mild and added some velveeta and the pre shredded Kraft parmasian romano Asiago.  I also used Panko for the bread crumb.  Turned out creamy smooth and buttery. The sauce really does thicken with baking. This is sooooo good will make again and now know I can substitute without messing up. The only way this could have been better is to add crumbled bacon. Everything is better with bacon. Just go for a run after eating. It all balances out.

userID:
13009707
Display Name:
Marissa
isPro:

followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am giving this recipe 4 stars because it is an awesome base....but I must tell you, that it can be elevated. For those of you who feel it was bland try using different cheeses.  I used fresh grated Parmesan, Romano, sharp cheddar, mozzarella, and Gouda.  I think s good smoked cheese would also be amazing. I will do that next time.  To the rue I added white wine, half and half, milk, and sour cream.  Blended that down until smooth.  I added the cheeses and labored to make it smooth and added cream or milk as needed (I don't measure).  I thought I had ground mustard but couldn't find it, so I used about 2 tablespoons Dijon, chili powder, garlic, pepper, and salt,  I also added ---- cooked, drained, and chopped applewood bacon, and chopped fresh chives.  (as if this wasn't fatty enough but hey...its Mac and cheese for peters sake).  You have to taste the sauce as you can and adjust to your taste.  Once you pour the noodles in, it's hard to fix the taste.  I cooked the noodles until it still had a little hard bite inside in very salty water and after I drained it I poured it into the cheese mix and let it cook until tender on low heat.  Poured it into a pan and topped with panko.

text:
I made this exactly as written except for a cheese substitution and it's delish but be careful with your cheese sauce and the amount of milk and roux ratio cuz mine came out a little more liquidey than I like. No big deal. I used a whole box of Barilla Pronto pasta which is awesome btw and still had too much sauce. I used Velveeta, sharp cheddar and gouda just because I like those flavors and the velveeta and gouda  add a great creaminess. I also added a pinch or two of nutmeg to my sauce cuz no cream sauce is complete without it. Don't forget to salt your cheese sauce and if you're using parm may I suggest salting at the end. Great mac n cheese I'll definitely make again! I took a pic but I don't see where to post with review, hopefully it'll magically appear.

I liked this recipe, i will make it again. I did make some changes. I am not a huge fan of cheddar so i used mexican blend instead and used about a half cup more.  I used the shredded parmesan not grated.  I added salt, garlic salt and pepper to the cheese sauce for a little flavor. The mac and cheese came out with more of an alfredo kind of taste. I t was delicious. I will continue to make it experimenting with the types of cheese. One suggestionwould be to not cook the noodles according to package but maybe halfway as they were extremely mushy when they came out as they continued to cook in the oven and i am not a fan of mushy noodles. Great recipe!

text:
I made this dish yesterday, and it was great. I did make some changes though. Instead of using recommend amt. of butter & milk, I used 1c of skimmed milk and only 2Tbs of butter. I made the roux with the butter & flour and added paprika,  cheese (Roth Ultimate Mac& Cheese) Parmesan salt, pepper & granulated garlic. I did not use bread crumbs. (Saved on calories). I added 1 beaten egg to the mixture poured over the Mac and topped it with sliced sharp cheddar and a bit of the Roth. Baked 30-40mins and the then broiled for 5 min or so until top was golden brown. Delicious!!!

text:
Awesome r ecipe!  I actually tripled this recipe to take to Christmas dinner and it did very well even in such a large amount  (I didn't have to alter the recipe really to make  it still turn out good).  The only thing I did differently was use half regular milk and half whipping cream (like some other users are suggesting) to make the sauce a little creamier and then instead of the parmesean cheese, I used American cheese instead  to help make the sauce more creamy and melty.  Instead of bread crumbs, I used crushed, lightly seasoned croutons.  Absolutely delicious and a big hit with the family!

I make this all the time! Great recipe for Mac n cheese that lasts all week. I use 16 oz of noodles instead of 8 and increase cheese to three and a half cups. Sauce thickens up perfectly. text:
This is an amazing side dish! I changed a few things and added a few things as well. I always double the recipe and since there's a lot of sauce, I changed the amount of milk. I add 5 cups instead of 6 and I use sharp, Colby jack, parmesan romano and smoked cheddar cheese as well. You can use as much of any as you would like as long as it equals - 4 cups of cheese. At the end of the recipe calls for the bread crumbs but sometimes I exclude those and add of veggies instead. My kiddos really like it with broccoli or cauliflower.  I add the veggies after I'm done baking the macaroni and cheese. It's a very easy recipe and very easy to make! One of my family's favorites !

text:
This recipe for Macaroni and Cheese is the original basic your grandma made ... needs absolutely NO tweeking!  BUT ... if you want to step it up a notch add any or all of the following to your dinner crowds taste >>> dry mustard powder, franks hot sauce, pureed celery/onion, saffron (big pinch), herbamare, actually anything goes!  I always add extra milk, as I do not like my pasta dry and only cook my pasta past crunchy ... this allows the sauce to become part of the pasta, and add on the flavor!  Try different cheeses in the bread crumb topping, anything goes!

text:
This recipe was ok, but that was only after I made a few modifications.  First off I completely agree with the other reviewers who said that this was a really bland recipe.  That's not necessarily a bad thing as it allows for you to experiment with the ingredients, however I think there needs to be some sort of disclaimer at the beginning  so that people know that they probably shouldn't follow the recipe to the tee.   To add a bit more flavor I added in some salt, onion powder, and mustard powder and I also used seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain ones.  I also had to cut the milk down to 2 cups and add in an extra 1/2 cup of cheese.   I feel it also important to note that you need to double the amount of pasta that the recipe says if you want mac&cheese rather than milky noodle soup.

text:
Super good! So creamy and easy to make. I used ingredients that I had on hand so I substituted the sharp cheddar for a Colby/Jack mix and coconut milk instead of cows milk and 16oz of Penne pasta. It had a much milder taste with the Colby/Jack so next time I'll get the cheddar. Also I didn't have breadcrumbs so I used Townhouse crackers which worked nicely since I also used unsalted real butter and I used smoked paprika which brought out a better flavor to the milder cheese. This is a great recipe and will keep it on the monthly family menu regularly.

userID:
14148263
Display Name:
Nelles

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good recipe. The cheese is your investment ingredient in any mac & cheese recipe so buy the best you can afford.  (If I'm buying U.S. cheese, I prefer ones that are made on the east coast.)  Substitute some of the milk if you want for another milk product such as sour cream or evap milk. Use whole milk instead of skim.  Always boil your pasta in well salted water or even broth.  If it's tastes 'floury',  you're cooking your roux too fast or not long enough.  Roux takes time.  I have good results with equal parts flour and fat and I like it golden brown.  If a recipe doesn't call for cold ingredients, room temp always works best.  Cold milk + cold cheese + hot pan equals bad results.  If you're using multiple cheese, work in your hardest cheese first so your soft cheese doesn't separate while your waiting for the other ones to melt.  And as with any recipe that doesn't list salt and pepper as an ingredient, season appropriately and taste as you go. Be careful with adding salt to this one though.  I agree this recipe needs a little dry mustard and you can add whatever else you want.  Maybe Garlic powder.  Sometimes I use cayenne to give it a little zip.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-09-03T06:18:06.207
helpfulCount:

text:
Very good and delicious, although prep time is a little longer than stated if you use low heat for roux and sauce, I prefer medium heat but stir more frequently and cuts the time in half. All in all I love this recipe and so did my guests, I just got done making it. After adding the noodles to the dish, and before baking I actually added another 1 cup of shredded sharp cheese, and 1 cup of Monterey jack cheese as a double blanket before addING breadcrumbs and it gave it an extra tangy cheesy kick. Of your a cheese lover I suggest this. Thanks for the recipe I'll use it alot.

text:
A great recipe! I've tried Alton Brown's recipe (tempering the egg was tricky) and others using gruyere cheese but this is definitely going to be my go-to from now on! I added some diced vidalia onion to the butter in the first step for more flavor, added some dry mustard before adding the cheese as some others suggested and used penne pasta because it was all I had. I think the larger pasta works very well with this - absorbs more and prevents the sauce from becoming too "gluey" between the noodles. Make sure to undercook the noodles by a couple minutes and rinse in cold water so they finish in the oven and don't get mushy. The only other change I made was that I sprinkled a layer of dry panko on top and used a thin drizzle of olive oil to prevent it from getting too dry in the oven. It worked perfectly and allowed me to use just a tad less butter overall. My husband and 3 sons just gobbled it up!

Delicious indeed. Next time I will make the following changes: use homemade breadcrumbs or panko, undercook the macaroni by two minutes,  use a stronger-flavored cheese instead of Parmesan, and add some herbs. I doubled the recipe and it filled a 9x13 pan perfectly to the brim.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really happy with the outcome of this recipe!! As others have mentioned, don't worry about the mixture looking too runny before you put the dish in the oven -- it will come out really creamy and thick! We adjusted the recipe just a little. First, we used 2 cups of heavy cream and 1/2 cup of milk -- Creaminess turned out beautifully. In addition, we used 1 cup parmesan, 1/2 cup gouda, and 1 cup sharp white cheddar cheeses. We wanted to grate the cheese freshly and honestly just grabbed what was least expensive in the cheese cooler at the store. What made a huge difference in taste for us was adding fresh grated black pepper (to taste) and herbs de provence (maybe a teaspoon into the creamy cheese mixture on the stove? -- basil, fennel, marjoram, parsley, rosemary, lavender, tarragon, and thyme -- you can get this in the Organics brand... I promise it's worth it!!). We will for sure be making this again :)

This is an awesome recipe for someone who is just sort of starting out and while I think there should be better instructions on how to make the roux, it's an over all simple, yummy treat for an in a pinch supper idea. Now I haven't played with any of the other foodies ideas but I do like to add some herbs, salt and pepper, and a little extra butter, and some cream cheese to mine. I don't find this dish tasteless or bland I think it's so creamy and rich and mine has a lot of flavor. I think is an awesome base for some creative tinkering. ^^ (have some in the oven right now~)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really good basic recipe. I read some of the reviews and incorporated some tips. I added garlic powder, celery salt, paprika and white pepper. I used a can of evaporated milk. And since I was serving this with caesar salad, I thought it would be fun to make breadcrumbs out of store-bought croutons, so I skipped the step of cooking the breadcrumbs in butter. I used old cheddar cheese and provolone for the shredded cheese, and parmesan and romano for the grated cheese. 

The only thing I wasn't sure of was the very next step after the roux. I added the milk and I wasn't sure how long to cook it before adding in the cheese. I thought I was supposed to wait for bubbles to form (as I often do when roux is involved), but after maybe 8-10 minutes of cooking it on medium, I added in the cheese. I wonder if I should have added the cheese as soon as the milk got hot ... I think it might have made for a smoother sauce. But overall, this is a great recipe and I'll definitely revisit it.

text:
Delicious! Great for a family meal or a single person.. if you want leftover's. It's not expensive and not hard to make. I made it the first time using the instructions exactly. This time I used a bit more than a pinch of Paprika, a 1/4th cup more shredded Sharp Cheddar cheese to make the sauce a bit thicker, it came out great! However, using the original recipe or your own touches don't worry if the sauce doesn't get think enough. Soon as it is in the oven for the first 10-15min it thickens up very nice.

city:

None
text:
I made this for Christmas yesterday. I sort of used this as a guideline, since this was my first time making homemade mac n cheese. I used a lot of the tips I read in the reviews and I doubled the recipe. Instead of three cups of milk, I used one part milk, one part condensed milk and one part sour cream. I also ended up using two pounds of medium cheddar and one pound Colby cheese (In my defense, I did double the whole recipe :P). I didnt use the colby cheese for the sauce, I sprinkled it over top. For seasoning, I used a tablespoon of dry mustard and two tablespoons of worchestsire  sauce to the cheese sauce. For the topping, crushed Ritz crackers. I also used the spiral noodles instead of elbow. This was so delicious, I was very surprised it came out so yummy! Definitely saving this one in the recipe box.

text:
Very good Mac 'n Cheese, but I will not put the bread crumbs on top again.  That was a miss.  Instead I top it with some great seasoning.  

Specifically "Kip" seasoning from Verstegen.  It's a dutch seasoning blend and I can only find it at the Dutch store. "Kip" means chicken so it's chicken seasoning and it consists of salt, coriander, paprika, pepper, ginger, mace, curcumin, celery seed, cumin, cardamom, chili, onion powder, fenugreek.  That adds a real nice tasty crust on top.

text:
So I made a few tweaks to this, after reading many of the reviews. Changes I made: I added a dash of salt, a teaspoon of garlic powder, 1 1/2 teaspoons onion powder instead of onions, 2 or so teaspoons dijon mustard. I used a whole can of evaporated milk (1 1/2 cups), half cup sour cream, one cup milk. Added half cup ish of swiss cheese as well. Used 2 cups noodles so just over 8oz. Instead of bread crumbs (can't stand them on pasta) I baked some hickory bacon at 425 for 23 minutes, and broke it into pieces before baking the whole thing. It was PHENOMENAL! The only complaint was from the 14 year old who thought we should cut the onion and dijon a smidge next time. I will be making this again. Thanks for the base recipe!

I would give this 4.5 stars. Very good basic recipe and the bread crumbs on top were so good when fried with a little butter. I read some of the reviews and after seeing that some thought it was a bit bland I sauteed a minced shallot and garlic clove in butter, then added the flour to make the roux. After finishing the sauce I was sure it was too much sauce for the amount of noodles, but I added it anyway and it thickened up perfectly in the oven. So delicious! With the garlic and shallot I would give it 5 stars!

Cons: it came out a little gritty. I'm not sure if I messed up the roux but I did follow the directions to a T. Sadly this was way too rich for me and gave me an upset stomach.

city:

country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner tonight - tried a different recipe about a week ago which was so not what we wanted. This is the creamy Mac 'n cheese that our taste buds craved. I did season it as several suggested, garlic and onion powder, fresh black pepper, dried mustard and some Siracha. Added just a little zing and really stepped up the overall flavour.  Mixed the panko with the melted butter and sprinkled on top to let it brown as someone else suggested. Used 3 cups of 1% milk, no need for condensed and sour cream - be patient with the roux and your sauce will be perfect. Used about 3 cups cheese total, some store old cheddar, (cheese shop) real 5 yr old cheddar and fresh parm. A keeper for sure - this will be my go to from now on. Thanks!

I love this recipe! I use coconut oil instead of butter, and even then I use just 3 tablespoons of coconut oil then the 1/4 cup they call for butter. And I also use unsweetened original flavored almond milk instead of "real" milk. And I honestly don't think you need 2 1/2 cups of cheese, but it's all about personal preference, I'm sure some people use even more, but I usually use about a 1 1/2 cups. The only reason I alter anything about this recipe is to help me feel a little better about eating something that's not so calorie friendly.

text:
I loved this Mac and cheese. But I was a little confused by the 1/4 cup butter and 2-1/2 T. Flour called for in the recipe. Then later in the instructions, we were told to "stir in enough flour to make a roux."  Please be advised that flour and butter should be in equal proportions for a roux:  2 T. Butter to 2 T. Flour.  Besides that little problem, this was amazingly tasty!!!  I loved the buttery bread crumbs on top.

userID:
12852660
Display Name:
ExceptionalSea
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i'm giving this 3 stars because this recipe is really only a base for you to give you an idea of what goes into macaroni and cheese - you'll definitely have to doctor it up / get creative with it to get the macaroni you want. 



i used 2 cups of milk instead of 3, and the sauce came out perfectly thick and creamy after baking in the oven. i also added 1 tbsp garlic powder, and some fresh cracked pepper and salt. i also used 3 different kinds of cheeses just because that's what i had in my kitchen: 1 cup colby/jack, 1/2 cup swiss, and 1/2 cup cheddar plus the 1/2 cup parmesan the recipe calls for. like other reviewers said using fresh grated parmesan instead of the pre-grated kraft kind might make it a little less grainy but overall i didn't think it was too bad. I didn't have trouble with graininess; the key is making the roux properly. i lived in louisiana for awhile - the trick is low heat and CONSTANTLY stirring with a whisk. you really want to get the flour all mixed in, so i added the flour slowly, alternating with milk when i made my recipe. and the longer you cook, the better. 



my macaroni wasn't bland, but i did use different cheeses and added a few spices. i also forwent the bread crumbs and just did more shredded cheese on top. it's delicious!
Review:
Rating:
2
dateLastModified:
2014-01-05T15:33:06.567

The ingredient list might not be correct. Three cups of milk turned out to be too much liquid for a roux of 2 tbl. butter and 2.5 tbl. of flour. Two cups would have been better. I had to add more flour later to thicken the sauce enough to melt the cheese. Perhaps there is a typo.

text:
I made this macaroni and cheese dish for Christmas dinner today.  I did not have milk, but I always keep powdered buttermilk mix in my fridge and use it any time I am out of milk.  (Well I have Vanilla Soy Milk, but it would've ruined this recipe) I used cheese ends from a package from Big Y (makes yummy mac n cheese w/ different surprise cheeses).  It is delicious!  I also added some chopped onion and dried thyme leaves for color and extra subtle taste.  I'll be making this dish more often....it's very easy and worth the effort it takes to make it from scratch.

userID:

Display Name:
Daniellepirelli

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night for the first time.  I've never actually had homemade mac and cheese, and neither have my kids, so I don't have anything to compare to.  But all I can rate about this is my own end result.  I added 1 tsp of onion, garlic powders to the sauce mix and sprinkled the topping with paprika, as others suggested. Didn't have any dry mustard. I also upped the serving amount, as we are a family of 6, making it in a 9x13 pan with 6 cups dry pasta, same amount of milk, and 3 cups of cheese.  Also used half evaporated milk and adjusted the butter/flour mix because there was more pasta.  Used fusilli pasta as well.  My biggest problem with this dish is the cheese "sauce".  The texture of it was terrible, not smooth or creamy at all.  I don't know if this had anything to do with my adjustments (it very well could have).  But I was expecting a silkier texture. It looked flawless while it was cooking in the pot, no lumps or pieces. Also, without the spices I added, this dish would be virtually tasteless. It even seemed to need salt, even after ALL that cheese in there.  Definitely a good base recipe, but needs some perking up.  Follow the advice of others and add things to it to get it just right.
Review:
Rating:
3

text:
This is a good basic recipe.  I saute some onion in the butter, and add the milk, and a little "gravy" flour to thicken, then add the 8 oz sharp cheese, that melts into the milk and onion.  Sometimes I grate different kinds of cheeses and add.  I tried using the Parmesan, no one was too crazy about that. I also add more cheese on top before I bake, and bread crumbs.  My family pretty much devours it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For this recipe I broke my cardinal rule of making the recipe, as written the first time.  I took some of the other reviewers suggestions and added a tin of evaporated milk, using whole milk to make up the rest of the 3 cups.  I also added some garlic powder and dry mustard to the sauce, topping the mac n' cheese with smoked paprika and Ritz crackers, mixed with melted butter.  Crazy good.  Could've used a little more salt to bring out the flavours but it was well received by everyone and my wife even had "thirds".  Will make again, but only for special occasions.  This recipe could be deadly if eaten on a regular basis ha, ha.
Review:

text:
Great recipe-I did cut the butter in half.  It was a bit "soupier" than I prefer, so I added  a few more noodles the next time.  I always use whole wheat noodles.  I loved the tang of the parmesan,  I used up a couple small bits of assorted cheeses in the frig (jarlsberg & something else) in addition to the cheddar, which was delicious.  My last addition was one and a half teaspoons of smoked paprika.  I usually add some to cheese or egg dishes.    If you've not used it before, start out with one teaspoon to four servings then you can increase to taste.  One last variation the second time was using minced jalapenos, last of the season.  The milk cuts the heat.

text:
I loved it, my kids loved it!  Followed the same outline above except I added a couple things

12 ounces uncooked elbow macaroni
2.5 cups shredded sharp Cheddar cheese
3/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese
3 cups milk
onion powder
dry mustard
paprika
salt
white pepper
2 1/2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
2 tablespoons butter
3/4 cup Italian style bread crumbs
paprika

i mixed onion, paprika, salt, pepper in with the cheese sauce, it wasn't as runny as i thought it would be either(reading other reviews).  Overall I loved it, my kids loved it too!

text:
First of all there is something wrong with the ratio's here!!! 8 ounces of pasta/ one cup?? It doesn't make sense! I wanted to double the recipe so logically I doubled the pasta AND everything else and I ended up with enough cheese sauce to make it twice!! Wayyyy too much!! I didn't even use all the milk it asks for, that's a crazy amount and dilutes the taste of the cheese. 
All in all the idea of this recipe is ok, but you have to modify it so much that you're not really making this recipe anymore. It needs more flavor... I added cheese wiz, garlic & onion power and Worcestershire sauce based on the suggestions of other reviews.
Less milk & more flavour required.

text:
Delicious.  This was better than I thought it would be and I even used cheap cheese.  I added a dash of dry mustard at the cheese melting stage, as well as salt and pepper.  Also, I didn't feel like dirtying another pan with the breadcrumbs, so I melted the butter in the microwave, mixed them with the breadcrumbs, sprinkled it on the noodles, then put the pan under the broiler for about 30 seconds after baking.  My entire family loved it.

text:
this is a decent basic recipe if you're just looking for approximately how much of the base ingredients you need. if you're looking for a step by step guide of how to make the perfect mac n cheese with no personal creative input, this is not the recipe for you. i made major changes to mine to suit my family's preferences. if you're having issues with the thickness of the sauce you either didn't make enough roux, or the roux isn't cooked thoroughly enough. getting down the roux will make the difference. i don't think the roux ratio for this recipe is enough.

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can rate this recipe only four. I'm not a mac and cheese guru, cause we just don't cook it where I live. So it's a first mac and cheese that I've made. But I can judge that without all those alternations and additions I've made this dish would be really bland. Firstly, I've used not only milk but also sour cream. Somewhere about 3/4 of milk and 1/4 of sour cream. The recipe omit salt but don't forget it to put, the roux is tasteless without it. Also I put 1 tsp of mustard powder and black pepper. I'm not going to try to a tee all these recipes of mac and cheese here, they are quite similar. All you can do is just to vary the amount (2-3 cups)and types of cheeses (cheddar, monterey jack, parmesan, swiss cheese, cottage cheese, mozzarela, muenster, etc.) Mix different liquids and sauces such as milk, cream, sour cream, evaporated milk, mayonnaise. Experiment with spices: salt, mustard powder, black pepper, cayenne, paprika, thyme, karri, herbes de provence will work.

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
9783751
Display Name:
Cooking in Tanzania
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
33
favoritesCount:
156
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT basic Mac and cheese recipe that can be spiced up to your own tastes.  I read a lot of the reviews after making this 4 times to find some hints for spicing it up a little.  Having traveled the US selling Napa wines, eating lots of delicious cheeses, I believe that if people find the recipe isn't cheesy enough, they simply need to try a different cheese. For instance, sharp cheddar has a distinct flavor different from medium cheddar. In our case, we don't have access to great cheeses unless we want to pay $37 for 4.5 lbs of imported cheddar from New Zealand.  Even with the "cheap" stuff from Kenya this recipe tastes great, so anyone living in the US with access to a great selection of cheeses, I really encourage you to try another one.  I don't think it's the recipe, it's probably the cheese.  On another note the sauce really thickens only AFTER adding the cheese.  We leave off the bread crumbs as I don't want the extra work and calories. Our family of 4 can nearly finish this in one meal without any other sides...delicious.

Kids & I loved it! I did make a few minor changes. Cooked 16 oz of macaroni in salted water until al dente. Increased cheddar cheese to 3 cups packed. Increased flour to 3 tablespoons. Used Italian-style bread crumbs. And sprinkled paprika generously. Bake in 9x11 pan for 25 minutes. Yum!

Annette Annette

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very good recipe.  I made a few changes to suit our lifestyle, but the "base" was superb!  I made this with all natural whole grain elbow macaroni, and I added salt to the water for cooking.  Next time, I will shave 2 minutes off of the macaroni cook time as the sauce softens the pasta up a fair amount.  I used a fine whole wheat flour (intended for bread and pastry), unsalted butter, plain almond milk, and medium cheddar (which is the cheese I had).  Unfortunately, all we had was some (powdery) Parmesan cheese leftover from before we started 90/10 Nutrition.  The flavor of the sauce with the Parmesan was wonderful, but the texture was very unpleasant.  Next time, I will use freshly grated Parmesan.  The sauce was a tad bland, so I added just a dash of garlic powder (and will use fresh puree next time), a good sprinkle of salt, 1/2 tsp. of ground mustard, and several cranks from my pepper mill.  It really was delicious, and I'm certain that next time we make it my family will be even more pleased than they were today!

A very good, basic Mac 'n cheese recipe.

text:
I burned the stove so that there are giant brown rings around the burners. The floor's sawdust-ed in cheese shavings and flour. Nearly all of the milk and cheese in the house is gone. There is a giant bowl of half-congealed noodles bulging out of the fridge. 
So saying, I would strongly recommend the use of only two cups or so--at the most--of milk. At least, I assume that's where I went wrong. I had to try and empty some of the milk from my saucepan. Thank goodness I had accidentally grated up an ungodly amount of extra cheddar cheese. This action may or may not have caused the darker splotches on my stove, but then, that could have been the plastic strainer that melted all over the upper burner. 
This did taste really good, but the sauce wasn't very thick because I was a dumba** and added all of that cheese, forgot the extra butter, did not actually bake the dish, and may or may not have overdone the noodles. 
I am going to rate this three stars, crawl under my bed, and never come out again.

text:
I made this recipe to serve 14 people. 
I had to change the recipe a little bit--but it turned out so well that I had to give this recipe 5 stars.  
I only had 6 cups of milk for the 10 1/2 it called for 
instead of 7 cups cheddar: I used 4 c cheddar, and, 8oz of the 2% or low fat Velveeta, cut into small squares.
Instead of 1 1/2 c Parmesan I used 1 cup Parmesan and Romano mix.
I loved this recipe and so did everyone at our family gathering.
Thank you for the recipe Judy! :)

text:
I do a lot of cooking, but try to avoid making really carb-heavy dishes.  I rarely eat mac and cheese, but found myself with a strong craving the other night and decided to give this a shot.  This was my first time making mac & cheese from scratch and I am willing to admit that maybe I'm missing something here, but I honestly thought the sauce was too runny, it had a gritty texture I didn't care for (maybe from the flour or dried parm?), and after cooking it in the oven for a half hour my noodles were a lot mushier than I like.  The flavor was Delicious however, especially with just a pinch of garlic salt added to my bowl.  I compared this recipe to many others online and they all seem to be similar so maybe this is just what homemade mac & cheese is supposed to be like?  But I was really hoping for a drier, smoother sauce.  I might try it again sometime, reduce the liquids, and double the amount of noodles.  there are also a number of suggestions other people have mentioned that might give me more of what I was hoping for.

I recommend baking it longer if you, like me, like a nice cheesy crust.  Both times I've made this (this year and last year's office Christmas parties, at different offices), I have used other cheeses and gotten very good reviews.  I recommend: 1 cup sharp cheddar, 1/2 cup white cheddar, 3/4 cup milk cheddar, 1/4 cup mozzarella and 1/4 cup parmesan.  That's a bit more cheese than the recipe says, but experiment with other delicious cheeses.
Review:

userID:
8696612
Display Name:
Tygerlilly
isPro:

17
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice now. The first time as it was written here, the second time with some tweaking. As written, this deserves 3 stars, good basic recipe, but a little bland, and not creamy enough for my taste. The second time, it's a 5 star recipe for sure. My changes: Used medium-sized sea shell pasta instead of elbow macaroni. Used 1 12 oz can of fat-free evaporated milk, 1/2 cup whole milk, and 1 cup of 1% milk. Had 1 lb processed American cheese cubes left over from another recipe, so I used those, plus 1 cup of sharp cheddar cheese. Didn't use the parmesan. Added 1/2 tsp onion powder, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp ground mustard, and a couple generous shakes of white pepper. Didn't sautee the bread crumbs before sprinkling them on top, because I figured there was already enough butter in this recipe. Sprinkled a handful of grated cheddar cheese over the top of the bread crumbs. Increased baking temp to 375 degrees, and baked for an additional 5 minutes to make sure the top got a little browned. With these changes it was excellent!

I've made this recipe twice now since finding it.  The first time was really good, but the second time was even better. Topped it off with some sour cream and it disappeared off of the plate!

text:
I couldn't wait to make this recipe after stumbling across it; however, it didn't blow my socks off. My husband hated the breadcrumbs. I didn't mind them, but probably could have done with less than 1/2 cup. My cheese mixture was a little thin when pouring onto the noodles but it did thicken up during baking. That being said though, the end result wasn't as cheesy as we had expected (I did use two cups skim milk and one cup 2% milk, so this might be why.) I also put in 1 cup peas (I put them in frozen during the last minute of boiling the noodles.) Finally, it was a little bland tasting. It needs something else for a little more flavor. It was an easy recipe and worth a try, but I won't necessarily make it again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/524087.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So...I made some changes to this. I used 1 small can of evaporated milk and fill the rest up to the 3 cups with milk. I cooked up about 6 strips of bacon, cut that into pieces and added that in, and I also sauteed 2 chicken breasts and cut them in to chunks, added 3 cloves of minced garlic to them and let them and added that in with the pasta and cheese sauce. I added about 1 T. of minced onion and some black pepper in with the sauce as well. It turned out great with my modifications, but I guess in making it again I would either make less pasta or a little more cheese sauce to compensate for the fact that the chicken soaks up some sauce as well.

text:
I forgot to add the parmesan cheese so I added about 1/2 tsp of salt, a pinch of nutmeg and about 1/2 tsp of ground mustard. Instead of all milk, I used a can of evaporated skim milk together with skim to equal 3 cups. It definitely needs more pasta though, maybe an additional 1/2 cup of uncooked macaroni noodles. I found my sauce was a bit clumpy, but that's my own fault - I should have waited for the cheese sauce to be completely smooth. Other than that, it was delicious!!

I didn't have exactly the same ingredients for this one.  I used Monterey Jack cheese mostly, just had a little cheddar on hand.  Also, didn't have the bread crumbs so used the last of some sour cream and chive potato chips and some Frenches fried onions, crunched in a ziplock bag. text:
This was really really yummy. However, I didn't like the taste of the Parmesan cheese in it, it was too overpowering for me (and my kiddos). I did change the recipe a little by doing what some others did and I substituted evaporated milk for 1 cup of milk, mixed in 1/2 cup of sour cream (in a double batch), and added about 1/2 cup of velveeta cheese. My husband loved how creamy it was. I think I'll try it again, but next time, I'll nix the Parmesan.

This was so easy & delicious! After reading through some other ratings & noting the ingredients in the recipe, I jazzed mine up with some spices. I chose parsley flakes, garlic powder, salt, pepper & onion flakes. The combination of spices really made this recipe pop! I also put in an assortment of cheeses depending  on what I have on hand (parmigiano, taco or casserole shredded blend etc)).DELICIOUS! This is hands down my go to recipe for Mac & cheese & I've yet to meet another I enjoy remotely as much.

text:
This is without a doubt the best macaroni and cheese recipe I've ever used! I love that it uses real cheese instead of Velveeta and other less-than-impressive cheese imposters. Plus, the crusty bread crumb topping gives it the perfect texture. However, I usually double this recipe's portions since this dish diminishes pretty quickly when placed before my family of ravenous mac-and-cheese enthusiasts. Also, I like to add a cup of Mexican-style shredded cheese to the sauce, and I use crushed Ritz crackers for the topping. This is sure to be the favorite at any party or dinner. Bon apetit!

country:
None
text:
In my quest to find the "PERFECT" mac and cheese, this one seems to a very good base to start with. It actually comes out creamy! My hubby and I left off the bread crumbs (just because we don't like 'em!) and just added the paprika on top. Several others have mentioned it was bland and we agree - I'm going to retry it with either nutmeg, dry mustard, or both! I'm also considering trying it with different cheeses, creams, etc. **One little piece of advice (and this might be common sense, BUT) - work on the sauce while the macaroni is cooking. Otherwise, the noodles get all sticky while sitting in the casserole!**

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe but it was kind of bland. I added salt, mustard powder, paprika, garlic powder, and basil. I also made it with 16oz of pasta by accident the first time and didn't miss anything so I always make that much. I didn't add the bread crumbs and just put it in a big bowl to mix and added seasoning to taste. The second time I made it, it came out runny so I think I under cooked the sauce. Make sure you give it a chance to cool before you determine it is too runny. If this happens, just microwave it for 2-3 minutes and it should thicken up. Then stir constantly while adding seasoning.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, so 4.5 stars. I made the following changes:   I used a silverware teaspoon and used only 3 lvl of those for the flour. Still 3 cups milk, 1/4c butter.   Omitted Parm, as I wanted to avoid the 'grainy'. I used one cup of sharp cheddar and one cup of colby/jack to make the sauce. Unfortunately, I still had a little bit of 'grainy' goin' on, but I think its because I was cooking it too high at first. So, totally my fault. Having said that, it wasnt bad at all.   I also found it a little bland, so I added 1 (measuring) tsp of salt after mixing the noodles with the sauce, and, since we love cheese, spinked in a couple more small handfuls of the cheddar, mixed thoroughly, and then topped with cheese (cheddar) instead of breadcrumbs.  This exceeded my expectations! I thought *I* made the best mac n cheese (so did my family). Now I *know* I do.. thanks to this terrific recipe. Thank you so much for sharing it; we loved it and have a new holiday staple ;-)

text:
So I jumped this up to 6 servings, and I still wound up with a whole lot more sauce than was needed for the noodles. I had to make double the noodles. I tried out a few of the user suggestions. One I really liked was the use of heavy cream instead of just milk. I also had to cut back on the amount as well. It called for 4.5 cups of milk and I used 2 cups of heavy cream and one cup of milk. And the sauce was pretty thick after adding the cheese. I also added spices to taste. Just go with what you like in your food. I used a mix of mild cheddar and monteray jack. It was good, but I have some work to do on it. Definately make more noodles.

This recipe is good, there's no denying that, but it's not great. Even changing things and adding stuff still leaves me feeling like there's something missing. However, this is still pretty good. Worth trying. I will be making this again, and probably with some frequency.

text:
I really like this mac and cheese recipe.  I like that it doesn't use any processed cheese. I add some spices to the cheese sauce before baking (salt, pepper, garlic powder, etc) and I let the sauce cook until it's fairly thick.  This cuts down on cooking time in the oven, and makes the final product less runny.

This has all the makings of a great Mac and Cheese dish but it needs someting. Not sure exactly what. It looked great appearance wise but it was dull tasting very dull. I did follow the recipe to the T.

text:
Personally, I don't like cheddar. I used old white cheddar in this recipe and mixed with the parmesean, I thought the flavor was good. I got ahead of myself and added the milk quickly to the roux. I wonder if that's why the dish wasn't creamy. The cheese separated from the macaroni. I will try it again, this time without breadcrumbs and with some seasoning.
